AWV
AWS
AWR |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Naval aircrewman operate airborne [[radar]] and electronic equipment used in detecting, locating, and tracking [[submarines]]. They provide information for aircraft and surface [[navigation]] and act as [[helicopter]]-rescue crewmen, and function as part of the [[flight crew]] on long-range and intermediate-range aircraft. Beginning in 2009, other enlisted aviation ratings that perform flight engineer or loadmaster duties in Navy aircraft will convert to the AW rating. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:Rating Badge AZ.jpg|100px]]
| style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Aviation maintenance administrationman]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |AZ | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Aviation maintenance administrationmen perform [[Clerk|clerical]], [[Military administration|administrative]], and [[Management|managerial]] duties necessary to keep aircraft maintenance activities running smoothly. They schedule and coordinated the maintenance workload, including inspections and modifications to aircraft and equipment. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:Rating Badge PR.jpg|100px]]
| style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Aircrew survival equipmentman]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |PR | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Aircrew survival equipmentmen are responsible for the packing and care of [[parachute]]s. They maintain [[Flight suit|flight clothing]], [[Life raft#Ship-launched lifeboats|rubber life rafts]], [[life jacket]]s, [[Oxygen Breathing Apparatus|oxygen-breathing apparatus]], [[Personal protective equipment|protective clothing]], and air-sea rescue equipment. The abbreviation comes from the former official title (still used informally) of [[parachute rigger]].[http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=3413 PRs are not just Parachute Riggers anymore], Navy story number NNS020906-08, 9/7/2002 |} ===Notes=== '''I'''{{note|AB}}: ABE, ABF, and ABH combine at paygrade E-9 to the rate of ''Master chief aviation boatswain's mate (ABCM)''.{{cite web| title = Enlisted Rank Insignia Aviation| work = Navy Data| publisher = U.S. Navy| url = http://www.navy.mil/navydata/ranks/ratings/av-rates.html| accessdate = 2007-06-18}}
'''II'''{{note|AF}}: AM, AME, and AD combine at paygrade E-9 to the rate of ''Master chief aircraft maintenanceman (AFCM)''.
'''III'''{{note|AV}}: AE and AT combine at paygrade E-9 to the rate of ''Master chief avionics technician (AVCM)''.
'''IV'''{{note|AW}}: 2009 AW rating merged with all other aircrew NEC's and changed their title from aviation warfare system operators to naval aircrewman. ==Construction ratings== {| class="wikitable" style="border:#25185d;" |- ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Insignia ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| General rating ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Abbreviation ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Service rating ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Abbreviation |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:Rating Badge BU.jpg|50px]]
| style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Builder (US Navy)|Builder]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |BU{{Ref label|CU|I}} | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Navy builders are like civilian [[construction]] workers. They are skilled [[carpenter]]s, [[plasterer]]s, [[roofer]]s, cement finishers, asphalt workers, [[masonry|masons]], and [[painter and decorator|painters]]. They build and repair all types of structures including: piers, bridges, towers, schools, offices, houses, and other buildings. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:Rating Badge CE.jpg|50px]]
| style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Construction electrician (United States Navy)|Construction electrician]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |CE{{Ref label|UC|II}} | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Construction electricians are responsible for the power production and [[electrical]] work required to build and operate airfields, roads, barracks, and hospitals. The work of a CE is equivalent to civilian construction [[electrician]]s, [[telephone]] and [[electrical]] repairmen, [[lineman (technician)|lineman]], and others. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge CM.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Construction mechanic (United States Navy)|Construction mechanic]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |CM{{Ref label|EQ|III}} | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Construction mechanics maintain many types of construction machinery including; [[bus]]es, [[dump truck]]s, [[bulldozer]]s, [[Road roller|rollers]], [[Crane (machine)|cranes]], [[backhoes]], and [[pile driver]]s. They work on gasoline and diesel [[engines]] and [[Transmission (mechanics)|transmissions]]. They also repair [[Electricity|electrical]], [[Hydraulics|hydraulic]], [[Pneumatics|pneumatic]] and [[Power steering|steering systems]]. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:Rating Badge EA.jpg|40px]]
| style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Engineering aide]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |EA{{Ref label|CU|I}} | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Engineering aides provide construction engineers with information needed to develop final construction plans. They conduct [[surveying|surveys]] for roads, airfields, buildings, etc. They perform [[soil test]]s, prepare [[Topography|topographic]] and [[Hydrography|hydrographic maps]]. They also survey for [[sanitary sewer|sewer]]s, [[Water pipe|water lines]], [[drainage]] systems and [[Earthworks (engineering)|underwater excavations]]. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge EO.png|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Equipment operator]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |EO{{Ref label|EQ|III}} | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Equipment operators work with heavy machinery such as [[bulldozers]], [[Electric shovel|power shovels]], [[pile driver]]s, etc. They use this machinery to dig [[ditches]], excavate for [[Foundation (architecture)|building foundations]], break up old [[concrete]] or [[asphalt]] paving and pour new [[Pavement (material)|paving]]. They grade and remove debris from construction sites, raise [[girder]]s, and move and set in place other pieces of equipment or materials needed for the job. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge SW.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Steelworker (United States Navy)|Steelworker]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |SW{{Ref label|CU|I}} | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Steelworkers rig and operate all special equipment used to move or hoist structural [[steel]], structural shapes and similar material. They erect and dismantle steel bridges, piers, buildings, [[storage tank]]s, etc. They work with steel shapes, plates and built-up sections used in the construction of overseas facilities. They are skilled in [[arc welding]], [[Gas metal arc welding|MIG welding]], [[Gas tungsten arc welding|TIG]] welding, and [[gas welding]]. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:Rating Badge UT.jpg|40px]]
| style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Utilitiesman (United States Navy)|Utilitiesman]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |UT{{Ref label|UC|II}} | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Utilitiesmen supervise and perform tasks involved in the installation and maintenance of plumbing, steam, [[Pneumatics|compressed air]] and fuel storage and distribution systems. They maintain [[air conditioning]] and [[refrigeration]] equipment, as well as sewage collecting and disposal facilities. |} ===Notes=== '''I'''{{note|CU}}: BU, EA, and SW combine, as follows: *at paygrade E-8 to the rating of ''Senior chief constructionman (CUCS)'' *at paygrade E-9 to the rating of ''Master chief constructionman (CUCM)''.{{cite web| title = Enlisted Rating Insignia, Construction Specialties| publisher = U.S. Navy| url = https://www.navy.mil/navydata/ranks/ratings/con-rate.html| accessdate = 2007-06-13| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070217113552/http://www.navy.mil/navydata/ranks/ratings/con-rate.html| archivedate = 2007-02-17| df = }} '''II'''{{note|UC}}: CE and UT combine at paygrade E-9 to the rating of ''Master chief utilitiesman (UCCM)''.
'''III'''{{note|EQ}}: CM and EO combine at paygrade E-9 to the rating of ''Master chief equipmentman (EQCM)''. ==Medical== {| class="wikitable" style="border:#25185d;" |- ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Insignia ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| General rating ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Abbreviation ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Service rating ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Abbreviation |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge HM.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Hospital corpsman]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |HM | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Hospital corpsmen are [[medical]] professionals who provide health care to service people and their families. They serve as [[pharmacy technician]]s, [[Emergency medical technician|medical technicians]], [[nurse]]'s aides, [[physician]]'s or [[dentist]]'s assistants, battlefield [[medics]], and more. All work falls into several categories: [[first aid]] and minor [[surgery]], patient transportation, patient care, [[Medical prescription|prescription]]s and laboratory work, food service inspections, and clerical duties. |} ==Administration, deck, technical, and weapons specialty ratings== {| class="wikitable" style="border:#25185d;" |- ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Insignia ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| General rating ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Abbreviation ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Service rating ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Abbreviation |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:Rating Badge BM.jpg|50px]]
| style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Boatswain's mate (United States Navy)|Boatswain's mate]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |BM | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Boatswain's mates train and supervise personnel in all activities relating to [[marlinspike]], [[Deck (ship)|deck]], and [[boat]] seamanship, and oversee the maintenance of the ship's external structure and deck equipment. They act as [[Petty Officer|petty officers]] in charge of small craft and may perform duties as [[master-at-arms]], serve in or take charge of [[gun]] crews, and [[damage control]] parties. Boatswain's mates are also responsible for the "deck side" watch. In port, three of the crew are on deck watch 24/7 (in hazardous areas such as war zones there are more than three, depending on ship's size). They are the Officer of the Deck, Boatswain's Mate of the watch, and Messenger of the Watch (usually a Seaman or Seaman Apprentice). They are stationed very close to the gangway and monitor all the comings and goings of persons to and from the ship. At sea the boatswain's mate of the watch is within ear shot of the conning officer (on the bridge). The boatswain's mate of the watch supervises the rest of the enlisted watch standers on deck. They include helmsman, messenger of the watch, and all the look outs. In port or at sea the boatswain's mate of the watch is charged with the responsibility of making all announcements to the crew; everything from chow call to general quarters (battle stations). |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge CS.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Culinary specialist (United States Navy)|Culinary specialist]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |CS | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |(Surface) (Subsurface) | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |CS CSS |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Culinary specialists prepare menus and order food items. They operate [[Galley (kitchen)|galley]] and dining facilities, manage large facilities, keep records for food supplies and financial budgets, and can even serve as [[flight attendant]] aircrewmen. They can also serve as a personal food service specialist, [[Household management|household/estate manager]] or chef for an [[Admiral (United States)|admiral]], the [[First Family of the United States|First Family]], [[President of the United States]] at [[Camp David]] and the [[White House]], to the [[Vice President]] at [[Number One Observatory Circle]] or for a [[commanding officer]] aboard ship or at shore bases. Ashore, Culinary Specialists often manage and maintain clubs, TAD hotels and Permanent Party naval barracks.{{cite web |title = Mess Management Specialists Transform into Culinary Specialist |work = U.S. Navy Newsstand |publisher = U.S. Navy |url = http://www.news.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=12134 |accessdate = 2006-12-27 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20040306060800/http://www.news.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=12134 |archivedate = 2004-03-06 |df = }} |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge CT.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Cryptologic technician]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |CT{{Ref label|CT|I}} | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |(Interpretive)
(Maintenance)
(Networks)
(Collection)
(Technical) | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |CTI
CTM
CTN
CTR
CTT |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Cryptologic technicians control the flow of messages and [[information]] and also conduct electronic warfare. Their work depends on their special branch: CTAs or administration cryptologic technicians (As of 01 OCT 07 CTA merged with the YN rating) perform administrative and [[clerk (position)|clerical]] duties that control access to [[Classified information|classified material]]. CTIs or interpretive cryptologic technicians handle radiotelephone [[communication]]s and foreign language [[translation]]. CTMs or maintenance cryptologic technicians maintain [[Electronics|electronic]] and [[electromechanical]] equipment. CTNs or networking cryptologic technicians handle computer communication. CTRs or collection cryptologic technicians handle all [[Morse code]] communications and operate [[Radio direction finding|radio direction-finding equipment]]. Finally, CTTs or technical cryptologic technicians deal with electronic warfare. CTTs are the first line of defense against inbound threats and anti-ship missiles. They also collect, analyze, and provide electronic intelligence support to commands throughout the world. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge EOD.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Navy EOD|Explosive ordnance disposal]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |EOD | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Explosive ordnance disposal technicians locate, identify, render safe and dispose of all forms of ordnance ([[Explosive material|conventional]], [[Nuclear weapon|nuclear]], [[Chemical warfare|chemical]], [[Biological warfare|biological]], [[Explosive#Military explosives|military]], and [[Improvised explosive device|improvised]]) both [[United States|U.S.]] and foreign made. [[Parachute]] or [[Helicopter]] insertion and deep-sea [[Underwater diving|diving]] capabilities are sometimes necessary to perform this mission. In addition to working closely with other military services, EOD technicians occasionally assist [[Law enforcement agency|civilian law enforcement agencies]].{{cite web | title = Navy Enlisted Rating Explosive Ordnance Disposal | work = Rod Powers | publisher = Military About.com | url = http://usmilitary.about.com/od/enlistedjob1/a/eod.htm | accessdate = 2006-12-28 }} |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge ET.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Electronics technician (United States Navy)|Electronics technician]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |ET | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |Surface
Nuclear Power
Submarine, Navigation
Submarine, Communications | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |ET
ETN http://www.public.navy.mil/bupers-npc/reference/messages/Documents/NAVADMINS/NAV2015/NAV15261.txt
ETV
ETR |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Electronics technicians are responsible for [[electronics|electronic equipment]] used to send and receive messages, detect enemy planes and [[ships]], and determine target distances. They maintain, repair, and [[calibrate]] all electronic equipment used for communications, detection [[Radar tracker|tracking]], identification, and [[navigation]]. Specially qualified electronics technicians are employed onboard [[Nuclear marine propulsion|nuclear-powered ships]] to operate the [[nuclear reactor]] and maintain its control subsystems. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge FC.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Fire controlman]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |FC | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |Conventional Non-Conventional (Aegis) | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |FC FCA |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Fire controlmen (FC's) maintain the control mechanism used in [[weapons systems]] on combat ships. Complex [[Electronics|electronic]], [[electrical]] and [[hydraulic]] equipment is required to ensure the accuracy of Navy [[guided-missile]] and surface gunfire-control systems. They are responsible for the operation, routine care and repair of this equipment, which includes [[radar]]s, [[computers]], [[Fire-control system|weapons direction equipment]], [[Fire-control system|target designation systems]], [[gyroscopes]] and [[rangefinder]]s. Fire controlman - Aegis (FCA's) maintain the [[Aegis Combat System]], an integrated naval weapons system on the [[Ticonderoga-class cruiser]] and the [[Arleigh Burke-class destroyer]]. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge FT.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Fire control technician]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |FT | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Fire control technicians maintain the electronic equipment used in [[submarine]] weapons systems. They are responsible for the operation and maintenance of the complex electronic, electrical and mechanical [[Military equipment|equipment]] required to ensure the accuracy of Navy [[guided-missile]] systems and underwater [[weapons]]. They are responsible for ship safety by recognizing and analyzing data from several critical systems including sonar, radar, periscope, radio, and torpedo inputs. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge GM.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Gunner's mate]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |GM | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Gunner's mates operate and maintain all gunnery equipment, [[guided-missile]] launching systems, [[rocket launchers]], [[guns]], [[turrets]], and associated equipment. They repair [[electrical]], [[Electronics|electronic]], [[hydraulic]] and mechanical systems, and make detailed casualty analysis. They test [[ammunition]], [[missiles]] and their ordnance components. GMs train and supervise personnel in the handling and stowage of [[ammunition]], [[missiles]], and assigned ordnance equipment. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge IS.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Intelligence specialist]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |IS | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Intelligence specialists are involved in collecting and interpreting [[Military intelligence|intelligence]] especially secret information about enemies or potential enemies. They analyze [[photographs]] and prepare [[charts]], [[maps]], and reports that describe in detail the strategic situation all over the world. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge IT.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Information systems technician (United States Navy)|Information systems technician]]''' (Surface)
'''Information Systems Technician Submarines''' (Submarine) | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |IT{{Ref label|IT|II}}
ITS | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Information systems technicians design, install, operate, and maintain state-of-the-art informations systems. This technology includes [[LAN|local]] and [[wide area network]]s, [[Mainframe computer|mainframe]], [[minicomputer|mini]] and [[microcomputer]] systems and associated [[computer peripheral|peripheral]] devices. They also write programs to handle the collection, manipulation and distribution of data for a wide variety of applications and requirements. They perform the functions of a [[Systems analyst|computer system analyst]], operate [[telecommunications|telecommunications systems]] including automated networks and the full spectrum of [[Parallel communications|data links]] and [[Electronic circuit|circuit]]s.{{cite web | title = Navy Enlisted Rating Descriptions Information System Technician (IT) | work = U.S. Military about.com | publisher = U.S. Navy | url = http://usmilitary.about.com/od/enlistedjob1/a/it.htm | accessdate = 2006-12-27 }} |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge LN.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Legalman]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |LN | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Legalmen are the Navy's [[paralegal]]s. They assist Staff Judge Advocates in the proper administration of military justice and administrative [[law]], such as [[courts-martial]], [[nonjudicial punishment]], and administrative separation. They work in Region Legal Service Offices (RLSO), Defense Service Offices, aboard aircraft carriers and large amphibious ships, and at various independent duty locations. Legalmen assist service members, retirees, and their family members with powers of attorney, wills, [[Tax return (United States)|tax return]]s, [[voter registration]] procedures, [[United States nationality law|immigration]] and customs regulations, [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] regulations, and [[Veterans benefits|veterans' benefits]]. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge SK.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Logistics specialist]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |LS | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |(Surface) (Subsurface) | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |LS LSS |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Logistics specialists manage inventories and issuance of repair parts/general supplies and specialized supplies (e.g., personal flight gear for naval aircrews or specialized combat equipment for Navy SEALs or Naval Military Construction Battalion "Seabees"), as well as distribute mail for naval ships, submarines, aviation squadrons, and shore-based activities. They procure, receive, store and issue material and repair selected components. They utilize financial accounting and database systems to perform inventory and financial management functions. Additionally, they sort and distribute all official and personal mail, manage money order and stamp inventories, and maintain financial and inventory reports. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge MA.jpg|61px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Master-at-arms]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |MA | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Masters-at-arms uphold [[Law and order (politics)|law and order]] aboard [[ships]], shore stations, control access to naval installations, and deploy overseas with expeditionary forces and squadrons performing antiterrorism/force protection (AT/FP) duties. The basic duty of an MA is to enforce rules and regulations, maintain good order and [[discipline]], and protect life and property. Some other duties include conducting criminal investigations, personal protective services, take part in [[Corrections|correctional]] and rehabilitative programs, military working dog (MWD) handlers, small arms instruction, lethal and [[non-lethal weapon]]s training, and organize and train sailors assigned to shore patrol [[police]] duty. Their equivalents in the civilian world are [[detectives]], security guards, and [[policemen]]. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge MC.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Mass communication specialist]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |MC | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Mass communication specialists are [[Public affairs (military)|public affairs]] and visual information experts. They present the [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] story to audiences in the Navy and to the rest of the world through a variety of media. Mass communication specialists write and produce print and broadcast [[journalism]], [[news]], and feature stories for military and civilian [[newspaper]]s, [[magazines]], [[television]] and [[radio]] broadcast stations. They record [[Photography|still]] and [[Digital video|video photography]] of military operations, exercises, and other Navy events. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge MN.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Mineman]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |MN | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Minemen test, maintain, and repair [[Naval mine|mines]] and their components. They are responsible for assembling, testing, and delivering mines to the [[Naval mine#Mine laying|planting agent]]. They maintain minehandling and minelaying equipment. At sea, minemen primarily man Avenger Class mine countermeasures ships as well the new Independence Class littoral combat ships as a part of the MCM module. Their duties at sea include but are not limited to: operating mine hunting sonar, operating remote controlled submersibles in prosecuting mine-like contacts, rigging and deploying minesweeping gear as well as standing normal underway deck and combat information center watches.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.stripes.com/news/minesweepers-some-of-the-most-versatile-sailors-1.163878 |title=Minesweepers 'some of the most versatile' sailors - News |publisher=Stripes |date= |accessdate=2016-12-24}} |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge MT.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Missile technician (United States Navy)|Missile technician]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |MT | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Missile technicians operate and maintain the UGM-133 [[Trident II]] D5 [[missile]] Strategic Weapon System (SWS) carried aboard ballistic missile [[submarine]]s and at strategic weapons facilities. Missile technicians operate and maintain [[Electricity|electronic]], [[machine|mechanical]], [[hydraulic]] and [[pneumatic]] strategic weapon subsystems, test and operate the MK98 [[fire-control system]] and MK 6 [[Inertial Measurement Unit|guidance system]], perform classified targeting operations, and provide physical security to nuclear weapon systems. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge MU.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Musician (United States Navy)|Musician]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |MU | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Musicians play in official [[United States Navy Band|Navy bands]] and special groups such as [[jazz]] bands, [[dance]] bands and small ensembles. They give [[concerts]] and provide [[music]] for military ceremonies, religious services, [[parade]]s, [[Party|receptions]] and [[dance]]s. Official unit bands usually do not include [[String instrument|stringed instruments]], but each musician must be able to play at least one [[Brass instrument|brass]], [[Woodwind instrument|woodwind]] or [[percussion instrument]]. Sailors are selected for this rating through auditions. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge NC.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Navy counselor]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |NC | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | (Career)
(Recruiter) | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | NC(C)
NC(R) |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Navy counselors offer [[vocational]] guidance to [[US Navy|Navy]] personnel — individually and in groups — aboard ships and at shore facilities. They assess the interests, aptitudes, abilities and personalities of individuals and assist them in reaching their full potential. They are responsible directly to the command triumvirate (CO, XO, CMC) and report on many items such as retention, attrition, advancement, testing and various other facets of the career development program. Additionally, it is their keen eye and attention to detail that ensure personnel throughout the command are updated on current Navy policies in regards to career management, off duty education and administrative procedures, among various other responsibilities. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge OS.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Operations specialist (United States Navy)|Operations specialist]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |OS | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Operations specialists operate [[radar]], [[Radio navigation|navigation]] and [[Military communications|communications equipment]] in the shipboard [[Combat Information Center|combat information centers]] (CICs) or [[Bridge (ship)|bridges]]. They detect and track ships, planes, and missiles. They operate and maintain [[identification friend or foe]] (IFF) systems, [[electronic countermeasures]] (ECM) equipment and [[Radiotelephone|radio-telephones]]. They control and assist aircraft. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge PN.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Personnel specialist]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |PS | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Personnel specialists provide enlisted personnel with information and [[counseling]] about Navy jobs, opportunities for general [[education]] and [[training]], and promotion requirements. They assist enlisted members' families with [[legal aid]] or reassignments in hardship situations. Personnel Specialists keep records up to date, prepare reports, type letters and maintain files. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge QM.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Quartermaster]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |QM{{Ref label|QM|III}} | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Quartermasters assist the [[navigator]] and [[officer of the deck]] (OOD), steer the [[ship]], take [[radar]] [[Bearing (navigation)|bearings]] and ranges, make [[Depth Sounding|depth soundings]] and [[celestial navigation|celestial]] observations, plot [[Course (sail)|courses]] and command small craft. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge RP.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Religious program specialist]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |RP | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Religious program specialists assist [[United States Navy Chaplain Corps|Navy chaplains]] with administrative and [[budget]]ary tasks. They serve as custodians of [[chapel]] funds, keep religious documents and stay in contact with religious and community agencies. They prepare devotional and religious [[education]]al materials, set up volunteer programs, operate shipboard [[libraries]], supervise chaplains' offices and perform administrative, clerical and secretarial duties. They train personnel in religious programs and publicize religious activities. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge SB.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Special warfare combatant-craft crewmen|Special warfare boat operator]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |SB | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Special warfare boat operators ([[Special warfare combatant-craft crewmen|SWCC]] - special warfare combatant-craft crewmen) drive fast [[Motorboat|speedboats]] down narrow, winding [[river]]s, or the open [[ocean]] while performing high speed, medium range, or all weather insertion/extraction of [[Special forces|special operations forces]]. They participate in maritime interdiction operations, tactical swimmer operations, [[intelligence]] collection, operation [[deception]], and [[coast]]al [[patrol]].{{cite web|title=Special Warfare Combatant-craft Crewman|work=Rod Powers|publisher=U.S. Military about.com|url=http://usmilitary.about.com/od/navy/a/swcc.htm|accessdate=2006-12-28}} |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge SH.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Ship's serviceman]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |SH | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Ship's servicemen manage [[barber|barber shops]], [[tailor|tailor shops]], ships' [[uniform]] stores, [[Laundry|laundries]], [[dry cleaning]] plants and [[Shoemaking|cobbler shops]]. They serve as clerks in [[Base exchange|exchanges]], [[gas stations]], [[warehouses]], and [[commissary]] stores. Some ship's servicemen function as Navy club managers. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge SO.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[United States Navy SEALs|Special warfare operator]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |SO | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Special warfare operators are [[United States Navy SEALs|Navy SEALs]], which are the Navy's primary unconventional warfare units that conduct warfare at '''SE'''a, in the '''A'''ir, and on '''L'''and (SEAL). A SEAL's core skills consist of: [[sniper]], breacher, communicator, maritime/engineering, [[close air support]], [[corpsman]], driver, [[navigator]] (rural/urban/protective security), heavy weapons operator, sensitive site exploitation, air operations ([[parachuting]]/[[air assault|helicopter insertion]], etc.), climber, [[interrogator]], technical surveillance, and advanced special operations. SEALs oversee ocean-borne [[Naval mine|mine]] disposal, carry out direct action raids against military targets, conduct [[reconnaissance]], and secure beachheads for invading [[Amphibious warfare|amphibious]] forces. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge ST.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Sonar technician]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |ST | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |(Surface)
(Subsurface) | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |STG
STS |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Sonar technicians are responsible for underwater [[surveillance]]. They assist in safe [[navigation]] and aid in [[search and rescue]] and attack operations. They operate and repair [[sonar]] equipment and jam enemy sonars. Sonar Technicians operate, maintain and repair sonar systems, [[Anti-submarine warfare|antisubmarine warfare]] [[Fire-control system|fire control equipment]] and other various equipment associated with underwater detection, counter-detection, warfare and communications. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:Rating Badge YN.jpg|50px]]
| style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Yeoman (United States Navy)|Yeoman]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |YN | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |(Surface) (Subsurface) | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |YN YNS |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Yeomen perform [[Military administration|administrative]] and [[Clerk|clerical]] work. They deal with visitors, coordinate worldwide travel, submit passport applications, [[telephone]] calls and incoming [[mail]], and assist various ships, squadrons, staff commands, and special warfare teams around the world with administrative tasks. They write and type business and social letters, notices, directives, forms and reports. |} ===Notes=== '''I'''{{note|CT}}: Cryptologic technician now includes former rating of electronic warfare technician (EW).{{cite web| title = Enlisted Rank Insignia Administration| work = Navy Data| publisher = U.S. Navy| url = http://www.navy.mil/navydata/ranks/ratings/admin.html| accessdate = 2006-12-27}}
'''II'''{{note|IT}}: Information systems technician now includes former rating of cryptologic technician – communications (CTO).
'''III'''{{note|QM}}: Quartermaster QM now exists as electronics technician (navigation) ETV on submarines. ==Engineering and hull ratings== {| class="wikitable" style="border:#25185d;" |- ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Insignia ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| General rating ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Abbreviation ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Service rating ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Abbreviation |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge DC.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Damage controlman]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |DC{{Ref label|A|I}} | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Damage controlmen perform the work necessary for [[damage control]], ship stability, [[fire-fighting]]. They also prepare defenses against [[Weapons of mass destruction|chemical, biological and radiological (CBR) warfare]] attacks. They instruct personnel in damage control and CBR defense and repair damage-control equipment and systems. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:Rating Badge EM.jpg|50px]]
| style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Electrician's mate]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |EM | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |(Nuclear) | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |EMN |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Electrician's mates are responsible for the operation and repair of a ship's or station's [[Power station|electrical power plant]] and electrical equipment. They also maintain and repair power and lighting [[Electrical network|circuits]], [[Distribution board|distribution switchboards]], [[Electrical generator|generators]], [[Electric motor|motors]] and other electrical equipment. Specially qualified electrician's mates are employed onboard [[Nuclear marine propulsion|nuclear-powered ships]] to maintain the control subsystems in [[nuclear reactor]]s. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:Rating Badge EN.jpg|50px]]
| style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Engineman]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |EN | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Enginemen are responsible for internal [[diesel engines|diesel]] and [[gasoline engine]]s. They also maintain [[refrigeration]], [[air-conditioning]], [[Distillation|distilling-plant]] engines and compressors. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:Rating Badge GS.jpg|50px]]
| style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Gas turbine system technician]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |GS | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |(Electrical)
(Mechanical) | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |GSE
GSM |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Gas turbine system technicians are responsible for all [[Gas turbine|gas turbine engines]]. They maintain [[Marine propulsion|propulsion machinery]], including [[gear]]s, shafting and controllable pitch [[propeller]]s, assigned auxiliary equipment propulsion control systems, [[electrical]] and [[Electrical network|electronic circuitry]] up to the printed circuit module, and [[Alarm circuit|alarm and warning circuitry]]. They handle administrative tasks related to [[Gas turbine|gas turbine propulsion system]] operation and [[Maintenance, repair and operations|maintenance]]. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:Rating Badge HT.jpg|50px]]
| style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Hull maintenance technician]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |HT{{Ref label|A|I}} | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Hull maintenance technicians are responsible for maintaining [[Hull (watercraft)|ships' hulls]], [[Compression fitting|fittings]], [[Piping and plumbing fittings|piping systems]] and [[machine]]ry. They install and maintain all shipboard and shore based [[Plumbing|plumbing and piping]] systems. They look after a vessel's [[safety]] and [[wiktionary:survival|survival]] equipment and perform many tasks related to [[damage control]]. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge IC.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Interior communications electrician]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |IC{{Ref label|B|II}} | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Interior communications electricians operate and repair electronic devices used in the ship's interior [[communications system]]s, SITE TV systems, [[1MC]] (public address system), electronic [[megaphone]]s and other announcing equipment. They are responsible for the [[gyrocompass]] systems. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge MM.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Machinist's mate]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |MM | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |(Nuclear)
submarine (Weapons)
submarine (Auxiliary) | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" |MMN
MMW
MMA |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Machinist's mates are responsible for the continuous operation of the many [[engines]], [[compressors]], [[gears]], [[refrigeration]], and [[air-conditioning]] equipment along with other types of machinery onboard ships and shore installations. They are responsible for the ship's [[steam propulsion]] and auxiliary equipment and the outside (deck) machinery. Specially trained and qualified machinist's mates are deployed onboard [[Nuclear marine propulsion|nuclear-powered ships]] to maintain the machinery and piping in [[nuclear reactor]]s. Some nuclear machinists mates (engineering laboratory technicians) receive additional specialization in [[health physics]] and maintaining reactor chemistry. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge MR.jpg|60px]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Machinery repairman]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |MR{{Ref label|A|I}} | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Machinery repairmen are skilled machine tool operators. They make replacement parts and repair or overhaul a ship's engine auxiliary equipment, such as [[evaporators]], [[Gas compressor|air compressors]] and [[pumps]]. They repair deck equipment, including [[winches]], [[Hoist (device)|hoists]], [[Condenser (steam turbine)|condensers]], and [[Heat exchanger|heat exchange devices]]. Shipboard machinery repairmen frequently operate main [[Marine propulsion|propulsion machinery]], besides performing machine shop and repair duties. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:Rating Badge ND.jpg|50px]]
| style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Diver (United States Navy)|Navy diver]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |ND | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Navy divers are responsible for a wide variety of tasks like underwater ship maintenance, [[Ship construction|construction]], and [[Diver rescue|underwater rescue]]. They are assigned to [[United States Naval Special Warfare Command|Naval Special Warfare Units]] to provide diving technical expertise and supervisory support to all submersible operations.{{cite web | title = Navy Diver | work = Navy.com | publisher = U.S. Navy | url = http://www.navy.com/about/navylife/onduty/navydiver/navydiveunits/ | accessdate = 2006-12-28 }} |} ===Notes=== '''I'''{{note|A}}: The Navy has announced a merger of the DC, HT and MR ratings into repair technician (RT) is pending but has not announced a timeline.{{cite web | title = Enlisted Rating Insignia Engineering & Hull | work = Navy Data | publisher = U.S. Navy | url = http://www.navy.mil/navydata/ranks/ratings/eng-rate.html | accessdate = 2006-12-29 }}
'''II'''{{note|B}}: Prior to March 1 March 2014, IC and EM combine at paygrade E-9 to the rating of master chief electrician's mate (EMCM). After 1 March 2014, IC is moving to the Seaman ratings group.{{cite web|title=ESTABLISHMENT OF ICCM RATE AND REDESIGNATION OF INTERIOR COMMUNICATIONS|url=http://www.public.navy.mil/bupers-npc/reference/messages/Documents/NAVADMINS/NAV2013/NAV13320.txt|publisher=U.S. Navy|accessdate=20 December 2013}} ==Command ratings== {| class="wikitable" style="border:#25185d;" |- ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Insignia ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| General rating ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Abbreviation ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Service rating ! style="background:#25185d; color:white;"| Abbreviation |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:black;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge CMDCM.png|60px|center]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Command master chief petty officer]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |CMDCM | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Command master chief petty officers (CMDCM) are the senior most E-9 enlisted member of a United States Navy unit and are senior advisers to their unit's commanding officer. |- | colspan="5" style="background:#25185d; height:5px;"| |- | style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:black;" rowspan="2"|[[File:Rating Badge FLTCM-FORCM-MCPON.png|60px|center]] | style="border: 1px solid #25185d;" | '''[[Master chief petty officer|Fleet, force, and navy master chief petty officer]]''' | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center" |FLTCM, FORCM and MCPON | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | | style="border: 1px solid #25185d; text-align: center; font-size: x-small" | |- style="border:1px solid #25185d; background:#fff;"| | colspan="4" style="border:1px solid #25185d; vertical-align:top;"|Fleet master chief petty officer, force master chief petty officer, and Master Chief Petty Officer of the Navy are the senior most CMDCM to a fleet or force level command and the U.S. Navy itself who are senior advisers to the [[flag officer]] in command at that level. |- |} ==Examples of discontinued and changed ratings (1990–present)== {| class="wikitable" style="border:#25185d;" |- ! page.title: List of covers of Time magazine (2010s)

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2017}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of covers of ''Time'' magazine (2010s)}} [[File:Time Magazine logo.svg|200px|right]] This is a '''list of covers of [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] magazine''' between 2010 and 2019. ''Time'' was first published in 1923. As ''Time'' became established as one of the United States' leading [[newsmagazines]], an appearance on the cover of ''Time'' became an indicator of a person's notability, fame or notoriety. Such features were accompanied by articles about the person. A European, Middle East and African version, an Asian version, and a South Pacific version are also published in addition to the United States edition each week. This article distinguishes when the intercontinental covers are different. For other decades, see [[List of covers of Time magazine|Lists of covers of ''Time'' magazine]]. ==2010== {| class="wikitable" |- !width=10%|Date !width=45%|Person(s)/Object !width=45%|Caption |- !Jan 11 |[[Northwest Airlines Flight 253|Flight 253]] |Fear of Flying/The 4 Lessons of Flight 253 |- !Jan 18 |Why Your DNA Isn't Your Destiny |Why Your DNA Isn't Your Destiny/The new science of epigenetics reveals how the choices you make can change your genes-and those of your kids. |- !Jan 25 |A boy |Special Report: [[2010 Haiti earthquake|Haiti's Tragedy]] |- !Feb 1 |[[Barack Obama]] |Now what?
Obama Starts Over. |- !Feb 8 |'''US''': A squashed American football
'''Europe/Asia''': A child walking along rubble |'''US''': The Most Dangerous Game

page.title: List of people who have undergone electroconvulsive therapy

revision.text:
[[File:Bergonic chair.jpg|thumb|right|Use of electrical apparatus. Bergonic chair for giving general electric treatment for psychological effect in psycho-neurotic cases (World War I era)]] This is a '''list of notable cases of treatment with [[electroconvulsive therapy]]''' ('''ECT''').
==List of famous people== {{dynamic list}} * [[Linda Andre]], American author, activist, director of the Committee for Truth in Psychiatry (CTIP), and self-described [[psychiatric survivor]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-BE43JbezmgC&pg=PA70&lpg=PA70&dq=Linda+Andre+ECT&source=bl&ots=iZa90Jw6JY&sig=eW-ChX40TFRo5kAJA|title=Pushbutton Psychiatry: A History of Electroshock in America|first1=Timothy W.|last1=Kneeland|first2=Carol A. B.|last2=Warren|date=20 October 2017|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=dVM0O5VKwqYC&lpg=PA257&dq=linda%20andre&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q=linda%20andre&f=false Doctors of Deception: What They Don't Want You to Know about Shock Treatment. Linda Andre. 2009. Rutgers University Press.] {{ISBN|978-0813544410}}</ref> * [[Antonin Artaud]], French poet and playwright<ref>{{cite book | last = Barber | first = Stephen | title = The Screaming Body: Antonin Artaud – Film Projects, Drawings and Sound Recordings | publisher = Creation Books |date=February 2005 | isbn = 978-1-84068-091-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=3029396|title=Twelve of the Fifty-One Shocks of Antonin Artaud|first=Nigel|last=Ward|website=New Theatre Quarterly}}</ref> * [[Frances Farmer]], American film actress, who described standing in line with other girls at mental hospital waiting for shock treatments in the 1940's. * [[Tammy Wynette]], American country singer and composer, who described having a series of shock treatments for depression in her biography. * [[Dick Cavett]], American television talk show host<ref>{{cite book|last=Abrams|first= Richard| title=Electroconvulsive Therapy| publisher= Oxford University Press|year=2002| isbn=978-0-19-514820-6}}</ref> * [[Sue Clark-Wittenberg]], Canadian antipsychiatry activist, Director of The International Campaign to Ban Electroshock (ICBE) <ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BM2jTziyBtkC&lpg=PA164&ots=SoBlKnYw-u&dq=Wayne+Lax+of+Kenora&pg=PA163#v=snippet&q=Sue+Clark-Wittenberg&f=false|title=Mad Matters: A Critical Reader in Canadian Mad Studies|first1=Brenda A.|last1=LeFrançois|first2=Robert|last2=Menzies|first3=Geoffrey|last3=Reaume|date=20 October 2017|publisher=Canadian Scholars’ Press|via=Google Books}}</ref> * [[Ted Chabasinski]], American attorney, activist, and self-described [[psychiatric survivor]] who received ECT at six years of age.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cEYyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=P-gFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6688,5501446|title=Lawrence Journal-World - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/05/us/city-s-electroshock-vote-affecting-treatment.html|title=CITY'S ELECTROSHOCK VOTE AFFECTING TREATMENT|first=Lawrence K.|last=Altman|date=5 November 1982|publisher=|via=www.nytimes.com}}</ref> * [[Clementine Churchill]], wife of Sir Winston Churchill <ref>{{cite book|last=Purnell|first=Sonia|title=Clementine: The Life of Mrs. Winston Churchill|publisher=Viking|year=2015|isbn=0-525-42977-8}}</ref> * [[Paulo Coelho]], author of ''The Alchemist''<ref>{{cite book | last = Coelho| first = Paulo | title = The Zahir | publisher = HarperCollinsPublishers | year = 2006 | isbn = 0-00-722085-5 }}</ref> * [[Simone D.]], a pseudonym for a psychiatric patient in the [[Creedmoor Psychiatric Center]] in New York,<ref>{{cite book|title=The Madness Of Women: Myth and Experience|last=Ussher|first=Jane M.|publisher=[[Routledge]]|year=2011|isbn=9781136656323|page=85|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WSWpAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA85}}</ref> who in 2007 won a court ruling which set aside a two-year-old court order to give her electroshock treatment against her will<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mindfreedom.org/kb/mental-health-abuse/electroshock/simone-d|title=MindFreedom, article title Another victory against forced electroshock. Simone D. wins!|work=MFIPortal|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref><ref>http://www.narpa.org/SimoneDRelease7_10_07.pdf</ref> * Ken Donaldson, author <ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=z-MLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hlgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6410,2045149|title=The Evening Independent - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com}}</ref> * [[Duplessis Orphans]] Orphans of the 1950s in the province of Quebec, Canada, endured electroshock. * [[Kitty Dukakis]], wife of former Massachusetts governor and 1988 Democratic presidential nominee Michael Dukakis and author of ''Shock'',<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Dukakis | first1 = Kitty | last2=Tye| first2=Larry | title = Shock: The Healing Power of Electroconvulsive Therapy | publisher = Avery |date=September 2006 | isbn = 978-1-58333-265-8}}</ref> a book chronicling her experiences with ECT<ref name="dukakis newsweek">{{cite journal | last1 = Dukakis | first1 = K | last2 = Tye | first2 = L | year = 2006 | title = I Feel Good, I Feel Alive | url =http://www.newsweek.com/id/45609/page/1 | journal = September | volume = 18 | issue = | pages = 62–63 }}</ref> * [[Thomas Eagleton]], US senator and vice presidential candidate<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2008/mar/29/uselections2008.usa |title=The White House losers | date=March 29, 2008| first=Ed| last=Pilkington| publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |accessdate=2008-03-29 |work=}}</ref> * [[Roky Erickson]], American singer, songwriter, harmonica player and guitarist<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/2007-03-01/music/roky-erickson/ |title=Dallas - Music - Roky Erickson |publisher=DallasObserver.com | date=March 1, 2007| first=Darryl | last=Smyers| accessdate=2009-10-17}}</ref> * [[Carrie Fisher]], American actress and novelist<ref>{{cite book|last=Fisher|first=Carrie|title=Wishful Drinking|publisher=Simon & Schuster|year=2008|page=163|isbn=978-1-4391-0225-1}}</ref> Fisher speaks at length of her experiences with ECT in her autobiography ''[[Wishful Drinking]]''. * [[Janet Frame]], New Zealand writer and poet<ref>Frame, J. ''An Angel at My Table'', London, Virago, 2008 (autobiography)</ref> * [[Leonard Roy Frank]], is a published author, human rights activist, and self-described [[psychiatric survivor]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=MKcrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7PwFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6923,2289681|title=The Telegraph - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.madinamerica.com/2013/05/leonard-roy-frank/|title=Leonard Roy Frank: Activist and Pioneer - Mad In America|first=Kermit|last=Cole|date=15 May 2013|publisher=}}</ref> * Wendy Funk-Robitaille, author and self-described [[psychiatric survivor]].<ref>[https://www.amazon.ca/What-difference-does-make-survivor/dp/0968391303 "What Difference Does It Make" by Wendy Funk 1998] {{ISBN|978-0968391303}}</ref> * [[Judy Garland]], Singer, dancer, actress. * [[Harold Gimblett]], British cricketer<ref>{{cite web | title=Tale of a tormented genius | url=http://content-www.cricinfo.com/england/content/story/129485.html | first=David | last=Foot| date=June 9, 2003| publisher=ESPN CricInfo - Cricket News| accessdate=2007-06-12 }}</ref> * [[Julie Goodyear]], English actress from [[Coronation Street]].<ref>{{cite news|title=An end to Julie Goodyear's bad years?|url=http://www.express.co.uk/expressyourself/340350/An-end-to-Julie-Goodyear-s-bad-years|accessdate=31 December 2014|publisher=Daily Express Online|date=17 August 2012}}</ref> * [[Peter Green (musician)|Peter Green]], English blues guitarist, founding member of [[Fleetwood Mac]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.fmlegacy.com/Bios/biopeter.html| title=Peter Green Biography| publisher=Fmlegacy.com| date=February 7, 2009| first1=Jan| last1=Freedland| first2=John| last2=Fitzgerald| accessdate=2009-10-17| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090428011827/http://www.fmlegacy.com/Bios/biopeter.html| archivedate=April 28, 2009| df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/12/30/258376132/another-fleetwood-mac-album-thats-worth-a-damn|title=Another Fleetwood Mac Album That's 'Worth A Damn'|publisher=}}</ref> * [[David Helfgott]], Australian pianist<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denisdutton.com/helfgott.htm |first=Denis| last=Dutton | authorlink=Denis Dutton| title=David Helfgott: Beethoven on Prozac| work=Philosophy and Literature '''21''' (1997): 340–345 | publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press (archived at Denisdutton.com) | accessdate=2009-10-17}}</ref> * [[Ernest Hemingway]], American Pulitzer Prize–winning novelist, Nobel Laureate, short-story writer, and journalist<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/260825/Ernest-Hemingway.html |title=Ernest Hemingway (American writer) - Britannica Online Encyclopedia |publisher=Britannica.com |accessdate=2009-10-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/mar/26/health/he-42740|title=Revisiting Electroshock Therapy|first=Benedict|last=Carey|date=26 March 2001|publisher=|via=LA Times}}</ref> * [[Marya Hornbacher]], American writer<ref>Hornbacher, Marya. ''Madness: A Bipolar Life'', New York, 2008 (autobiography)</ref> * [[Vladimir Horowitz]], Russian-American classical pianist<ref>Plaskin, Glenn (1983). Biography of Vladimir Horowitz Quill {{ISBN|0-688-02656-7}} Pages 338, 387, 389</ref> * [[Vivien Leigh]], English actress and second wife of [[Laurence Olivier]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Capua|first=Michelangelo |title=Vivien Leigh: A Biography|publisher=McFarland|year=2003|pages=157, 169|isbn=0-7864-1497-9}}</ref> * [[Oscar Levant]], American pianist, composer, television and film personality<ref>{{cite book|last=Levant|first=Oscar|title=Memoirs of an Amnesiac|publisher=Bantam Books|year=1965|page=4|isbn=1-127-65584-1}}</ref> * [[Karolina Olsson]], the "Sleeping Beauty of Oknö" * [[Carmen Miranda]], Luso-Brazilian Singer, dancer, actress. * [[Michael Moriarty]], American actor<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mmuuuhp.com/demons050720.htm |title=Moriarty tames his demons |first=Yvonne |last=Zacharias | publisher=''The Vancouver Sun'' (at [http://Mmuuuhp.com MMuuuhp])| date=July 20, 2005| accessdate=2009-10-17}}</ref> * [[Sherwin B. Nuland]], American surgeon and writer<ref>Nuland, Sherwin (2001) [https://www.ted.com/talks/sherwin_nuland_on_electroshock_therapy My history of electroshock therapy], TED lecture (video).</ref> * [[Sam Phillips]], founder, Sun Records, discoverer of Elvis Presley <ref>{{cite book|last=Guralnick|first=Peter|title=Sam Phillips: The Man Who Invented Rock 'n' roll|publisher=Little, Brown & Co.|year=2015|isbn=0-316-04274-9}}</ref> * [[Robert M. Pirsig]], who later wrote about his experience in the autobiographical novel ''[[Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance]]''. * [[Sylvia Plath]], American writer and poet<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sylviaplath.de |title=Sylvia Plath Homepage |publisher=Sylviaplath.de |accessdate=2009-10-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bH82F5w-Y04C&lpg=PA534&ots=BCxwNO6Kzc&dq=Judy+Garland+ECT&pg=PA534#v=onepage&q=Sylvia+Plath&f=false|title=Psychiatry in Law / Law in Psychiatry, Second Edition|first=Ralph|last=Slovenko|date=3 March 2009|publisher=Taylor & Francis|via=Google Books}}</ref> * [[Emil Post]], American mathematician, died in 1954 of a heart attack following electroshock treatment for depression;<ref>{{cite book |editor=Baaz, Matthias |year=2011 |title=Kurt Gödel and the Foundations of Mathematics: Horizons of Truth |edition=1st |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=9781139498432}}</ref><ref>Urquhart (2008), p. 430.</ref> he was 57. * [[Bud Powell]], American jazz musician<ref>{{cite book|last=Leland|first=John |authorlink=John Leland (journalist)|title=Hip, the history|publisher=HarperCollins|year=2004|page=123|isbn=0-06-052817-6}}</ref> * [[Lou Reed]], American singer-songwriter <ref>McNeil, Legs; McCain, Gillian, [https://books.google.com/books?id=mkG7Y6_J7pUC&printsec=frontcover ''Please Kill Me: The Uncensored Oral History of Punk''], Grove Press (1996). Cf. [https://books.google.com/books?id=mkG7Y6_J7pUC&printsec=frontcover&dq=please+kill+me&hl=en&ei=ZQBrTvWmBYPZgQer2IyGBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Rockland%20County&f=false pp.3–4]</ref><ref>{{cite web| first=Alex| last=Dobuzinskis| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024052610/http://valleynews.com/SantaClaritaValley/Blogs/Arts-Entertainment/Music/Blog~153612.aspx| archivedate=2007-10-24| publisher=Valley News Blog| url=http://valleynews.com/SantaClaritaValley/Blogs/Arts-Entertainment/Music/Blog~153612.aspx| title= Can electroshock therapy make you a better singer?| date=November 22, 2006}}</ref> * [[Marilyn Rice]], anti-electroconvulsive therapy activist<ref name="theatlantic2001">{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2001/02/shock-and-disbelief/302114/ |title=Shock and Disbelief |publisher=The Atlantic |date=2015-05-19 |accessdate=2015-06-16}}</ref> * [[Paul Robeson]], American [[Bass (voice type)|bass]] singer and actor<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/31608914|title=Paul Robeson|last=B.|first=Duberman, Martin|date=1996|origyear=1989|publisher=New Press|isbn=156584288X|location=New York|oclc=31608914}}</ref> * [[Yves Saint-Laurent (designer)|Yves Saint-Laurent]], French fashion designer<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebiographychannel.co.uk/biography_story/931:1087/1/Yves_Saint_Laurent.htm |title=The Biography Channel – Yves Saint Laurent Biography |publisher=TheBiographyChannel.co.uk |date=2009-09-11 |accessdate=2009-10-17}}</ref> * [[Peggy S. Salters]], from South Carolina, in 2005 became the first survivor of electroshock treatment in the United States to win a jury verdict and a large money judgment ($635,177) in compensation for extensive permanent amnesia and cognitive disability caused by the procedure<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peoplewho.org/documents/ctip.ectverdict.htm|title=People Who, untitled article|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref> * [[Edie Sedgwick]], American socialite and [[Warhol Superstar]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Stein|first= Jean|author2=Plimpton, George |title=Edie: American Girl|publisher=Grove Press|year=1994|pages=390, 398|isbn=0-8021-3410-6}}</ref> * [[Gene Tierney]], American actress<ref>{{cite book|last=Shorter|first=Edward |author2=Healy, David |title=Shock Therapy: A History of Electroconvulsive Treatment in Mental Illness|publisher=Rutgers University Press|year=2007|page=156|isbn=0-8135-4169-7}}</ref> * [[Townes van Zandt]], American country singer-songwriter<ref>[[Be Here to Love Me|Biographical film]]</ref> * [[David Foster Wallace]], American writer <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/15/books/15wallace.html |title=David Foster Wallace, Influential Writer, dies at 46 |first=Bruce| last=Weber| date= September 14, 2008 |publisher=[[The New York Times]] }}</ref>
