{{other people}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox scientist |birth_name = Paul Charles William Davies |image = Paul Davies 2016.jpg |image_size = 150px |caption = Davies in 2016 |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1946|4|22}} |birth_place = [[London]], [[England]] |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] |fields = [[Physicist]] |workplaces = [[Arizona State University]]
[[University of Cambridge]]
[[University of Adelaide]]
[[Macquarie University]]
[[University of Newcastle upon Tyne|University of Newcastle]] |alma_mater = [[University College London]] |doctoral_advisor = [[M. J. Seaton|Michael J. Seaton]]{{MathGenealogy|id=103961}}
[[Sigurd Zienau]] | thesis_title = Contributions to theoretical physics: (i) Radiation damping in the optical continuum; (ii) A quantum theory of Wheeler–Feynman electrodynamics | thesis_url = http://www.theses.com | thesis_year = 1970 |academic_advisors = [[Fred Hoyle]] ([[postdoctoral research|postdoc]] advisor) |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = [[Fulling–Davies–Unruh effect]]
[[Bunch–Davies vacuum state]] |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |awards = [[Templeton Prize]] (1995)
[[Kelvin Medal]] (2001)
[[Faraday Prize]] (2002)
[[Klumpke-Roberts Award]] (2011) |signature = |footnotes = |website = http://cosmos.asu.edu/ }} '''Paul Charles William Davies''', [[Order of Australia|AM]] (born 22 April 1946) is an [[United Kingdom|English]] [[physicist]], writer and [[Television presenter|broadcaster]], a professor at [[Arizona State University]] as well as the Director of BEYOND: Center for Fundamental Concepts in Science. He is affiliated with the Institute for Quantum Studies at Chapman University in California. He has held previous academic appointments at the [[University of Cambridge]], [[University College London]], [[Newcastle University|University of Newcastle upon Tyne]], [[University of Adelaide]] and [[Macquarie University]]. His research interests are in the fields of [[physical cosmology|cosmology]], [[quantum field theory]], and [[astrobiology]]. He proposed that a [[one-way trip to Mars]] could be a viable option. In 2005, he took up the chair of the [[SETI]]: Post-Detection Science and Technology Taskgroup of the [[International Academy of Astronautics]]. He is also an adviser to the Microbes Mind Forum. ==Education== Davies was brought up in [[Finchley]], [[London]]. He attended [[Woodhouse College|Woodhouse Grammar School]] and then studied physics at [[University College London]], gaining a first class [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in 1967. In 1970, he completed his [[PhD]] under the supervision of [[Michael Seaton|Michael J. Seaton]] and [[Sigurd Zienau]] at University College London.{{cite thesis |degree=PhD |first=Paul|last=Davies |title=Contributions to theoretical physics: (i) Radiation damping in the optical continuum; (ii) A quantum theory of Wheeler–Feynham electrodynamics |publisher=[[University College London]] |date=1970 |url=http://www.theses.com}}{{subscription required}} He then carried out [[postdoctoral research]] under [[Fred Hoyle]] at the [[University of Cambridge]]. ==Scientific research== Davies' inquiries have included [[theoretical physics]], [[cosmology]], and [[astrobiology]]; his research has been mainly in the area of [[quantum field theory in curved spacetime]]. His notable contributions are the so-called [[Fulling–Davies–Unruh effect]], according to which an observer accelerating through empty space will be subject to a bath of induced [[thermal radiation]], and the [[Bunch–Davies vacuum state]], often used as the basis for explaining the fluctuations in the [[cosmic background radiation]] left over from the [[big bang]]. A paper co-authored with Stephen Fulling and [[William Unruh]] was the first to suggest that [[black holes]] evaporating via the [[Stephen Hawking|Hawking]] effect lose mass as a result of a flux of negative energy streaming into the hole from the surrounding space. Davies has had a longstanding association with the problem of [[Arrow of time|time's arrow]], and was also an early proponent of the theory that life on Earth may have come from Mars cocooned in rocks ejected by asteroid and comet impacts. During his time in Australia he helped establish the Australian Centre for Astrobiology. Davies was a co-author of [[Felisa Wolfe-Simon]] on the ''Science'' article "A Bacterium That Can Grow by Using Arsenic Instead of Phosphorus".{{cite journal | last1 = Wolfe-Simon | first1 = F. | last2 = Blum | first2 = J. S. | last3 = Kulp | first3 = T. R. | last4 = Gordon | first4 = G. W. | last5 = Hoeft | first5 = S. E. | last6 = Pett-Ridge | first6 = J. | last7 = Stolz | first7 = J. F. | last8 = Webb | first8 = S. M. | last9 = Weber | first9 = P. K. | last10 = Davies | first10 = P. C. W. | last11 = Anbar | first11 = A. D. | last12 = Oremland | first12 = R. S.| title = A Bacterium That Can Grow by Using Arsenic Instead of Phosphorus | journal = Science | year = 2011 | volume = 332 | issue = 6034 | pages = 1163–1166 | doi = 10.1126/science.1197258 | pmid = 21127214|bibcode = 2011Sci...332.1163W }} Reports refuting the most significant aspects of the original results were published in the same journal in 2012, including by researchers from the University of British Columbia and Princeton University.{{Cite journal | last1 = Erb | first1 = T. J. | last2 = Kiefer | first2 = P. | last3 = Hattendorf | first3 = B. | last4 = Gunther | first4 = D. | last5 = Vorholt | first5 = J. A. | title = GFAJ-1 is an Arsenate-Resistant, Phosphate-Dependent Organism | doi = 10.1126/science.1218455 | journal = Science | volume = 337 | issue = 6093 | pages = 467–470 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22773139| pmc = |bibcode = 2012Sci...337..467E }} Davies is Principal Investigator at [[Arizona State University]]'s Center for Convergence of Physical Science and Cancer Biology. This is part of a program set up by the [[National Institutes of Health]]'s [[National Cancer Institute]] to involve physicists in cancer research which has set up a network of 12 [[Physical Sciences-Oncology Center]]s.{{cite web|url=http://cancer-insights.asu.edu/about-us/|title=Center for Convergence of Physical Science and Cancer Biology|accessdate=28 June 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/nov/18/cancer-evolution-bygone-biological-age|title=Cancer can teach us about our own evolution|first=Paul|last=Davies|newspaper= [[The Guardian]]|date=18 November 2012}}{{cite web|title=Cancer from a physicist's perspective: a new theory of cancer| publisher=[[New Scientist]] | date=19 Jun 2013 | first=Paul | last=Davies | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yoQYh0qPtz8 }} ==Awards== Davies' talent as a communicator of science has been recognized in [[Australia]] by an [[Advance Australia Award]] and two [[Eureka Prize]]s, and in the UK by the 2001 [[Kelvin Medal]] and Prize by the [[Institute of Physics]], and the 2002 [[Faraday Prize]] by The [[Royal Society]]. Davies received the [[Templeton Prize]] in 1995. Davies was made a member of the [[Order of Australia]] in the 2007 Queen's birthday honours list. The minor planet [[6870 Pauldavies]] is named after him. ==Media work== Davies writes and comments on scientific and philosophical issues. He made a documentary series for [[BBC Radio 3]], and two Australian television series, ''The Big Questions'' and ''More Big Questions''. His BBC documentary ''The Cradle of Life'' featured the subject of his [[Faraday Prize]] lecture. He writes regularly for newspapers and magazines worldwide. He has been guest on numerous radio and television programmes including the children's podcast programme ''[[Ask A Biologist]]''. A 2007 opinion piece "Taking Science on Faith" in the ''[[New York Times]]'',{{cite news| first=Paul|last=Davies| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/24/opinion/24davies.html| newspaper = [[New York Times]]| title=Taking Science on Faith| date=2007-11-24| accessdate=2010-10-02}} generated controversy over its exploration of the role of [[faith]] in scientific inquiry. Davies argued that the faith scientists have in the immutability of [[physical laws]] has origins in [[Christian theology]], and that the claim that science is "free of faith" is "manifestly bogus." The [[Edge Foundation]] presented a criticism of Davies' article written by [[Jerry Coyne]], [[Nathan Myhrvold]], [[Lawrence Krauss]], [[Scott Atran]], [[Sean M. Carroll|Sean Carroll]], [[Jeremy Bernstein]], [[PZ Myers]], [[Lee Smolin]], [[John Horgan (American journalist)|John Horgan]], [[Alan Sokal]] and a response by Davies beginning ''I was dismayed at how many of my detractors completely misunderstood what I had written. Indeed, their responses bore the hallmarks of a superficial knee-jerk reaction to the sight of the words "science" and "faith" juxtaposed.'' {{cite web |author=Jerry Coyne |author2=Nathan Myhrvold |author3=Lawrence Krauss |author4=Scott Atran |author5=Sean Carroll |author6=Jeremy Bernstein |author7=PZ Myers |author8=Lee Smolin |author9=John Horgan |author10=Alan Sokal |title=On "Taking Science on Faith" by Paul C. Davies |url=http://www.edge.org/discourse/science_faith.html |publisher=[[Edge.org]] |accessdate=2010-09-28 }} While atheists [[Richard Dawkins]] {{cite book |author=Richard Dawkins |date=2006 |chapter=A Deeply Religious Non-Believer |title=The God Delusion |url= |publisher=[[Mariner Books]] |pages=31–50 |isbn=978-0-618-91824-9 }} and [[Victor J. Stenger]] {{cite web |author = Victor J. Stenger |title = Review of ''The Cosmic Blueprint'' |url = http://www.colorado.edu/philosophy/vstenger/RelSci/CosmicBlueprint.htm |work = Science & Theology News |publisher = [[University of Colorado at Boulder|University of Colorado]] |accessdate = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100607135118/http://www.colorado.edu/philosophy/vstenger/RelSci/CosmicBlueprint.htm |archivedate = 7 June 2010 |df = dmy-all }} have criticised Davies' public stance on [[science and religion]], others, including the [[John Templeton Foundation]], have praised his work. Davies wrote an article in the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' describing the background to the December 2010 [[GFAJ-1|arsenic bacteria]] press conference and stating that he supported the finding of [[Felisa Wolfe-Simon]] that arsenic can replace phosphorus because "I had the advantage of being unencumbered by knowledge. I dropped chemistry at the age of 16, and all I knew about arsenic came from [[Agatha Christie]] novels."{{cite news | newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]] | title=The 'Give Me a Job' Microbe | last=Davies | first=Paul | date=4 December 2010 | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703989004575652940497021092 | accessdate=5 December 2010 }} He also made the statement, "Well, I would be astonished if this was the only arsenic-based organism on Earth and Felisa just happened to scrape it up from the bottom of Mono Lake on the first try, It's quite clear that it is the tip of an iceberg. I think it's a window into a whole new world of microbiology. And as a matter of fact, she already has 20 or so candidate other organisms that we're very anxious to take a look at. I think we're going to see a whole new domain of life here."{{cite news |title=Bacterium calls for biology rewrite: Transcript |url=http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/scienceshow/bacterium-calls-for-biology-rewrite/2959830#transcript |work=[[ABC (Australian TV channel)|ABC.net.au]] |date=4 December 2010 |accessdate=24 October 2018}} It was later independently demonstrated that the organism's DNA contained no arsenic at all.{{cite news | title = Studies refute arsenic bug claim | date = 9 July 2012 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-18770964 | work = [[BBC News]] | accessdate = 2012-07-10}}{{cite journal | title = GFAJ-1 Is an Arsenate-Resistant, Phosphate-Dependent Organism | journal = Science | date = 8 July 2012 | author = Tobias J. Erb | display-authors = 4 | author2 = Patrick Kiefer | author3 = Bodo Hattendorf | author4 = Detlef Gunter | author5 = Julia Vorholt|doi=10.1126/science.1218455 | url = http://www.sciencemag.org/content/early/2012/07/06/science.1218455 | accessdate = 2012-07-10 | pmid=22773139 | volume=337 | issue=6093 | pages=467–70|bibcode = 2012Sci...337..467E }}[http://rrresearch.fieldofscience.com/2012/01/csclmass-spectrometry-data.html RRResearch] By Rosie Redfield. 16 January 2012{{cite journal | title = Absence of Detectable Arsenate in DNA from Arsenate-Grown GFAJ-1 Cells | journal = Science | date = 8 July 2012 | author = Marshall Louis Reaves |display-authors=4 |author2=Sunita Sinha |author3=Joshua Rabinowitz |author4=Leonid Kruglyak |author5=Rosemary Redfield |doi=10.1126/science.1219861 | url = http://www.sciencemag.org/content/early/2012/07/06/science.1219861 | accessdate = 2012-07-10 | pmid=22773140 | pmc=3845625 | volume=337 | issue=6093 | pages=470–3|arxiv = 1201.6643 |bibcode = 2012Sci...337..470R }} In a similar vein, a 2013 article in ''The Guardian'' by Davies suggested that the origin of life will be uncovered through [[information theory]] rather than chemistry.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jan/13/secret-life-unveiled-chemistry-lab#start-of-comments | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Paul | last=Davies | title=The secret of life won't be cooked up in a chemistry lab | date=13 January 2013}} Concerns have been raised about his responsibility as one of Wolfe-Simon's co-authors.{{cite web |first=Rosie |last=Redfield |title=Authorship without responsibility? |url=http://rrresearch.fieldofscience.com/2012/02/authorship-without-responsibility.html |work=RRResearch |date=3 February 2012 |accessdate=24 October 2018}} ==In popular culture== * The novel ''[[Naive, Super]]'', by Norwegian writer [[Erlend Loe]] (translated by Tor Ketil Solberg), published in 1996, refers to Davies frequently. * ''Numbers'' (season 5, episode 12) refers to Paul Davies' Cosmic Think Tank at Arizona State. * ''[[Lawrence Leung's Unbelievable]]'' (season 1, episode 3), Leung interviews Paul Davies on Alien abduction, where Paul admits to having experienced [[sleep paralysis]]. * The novel ''The Extinction Machine'', by American writer [[Jonathan Maberry]], published in 2013, refers to Paul Davies. * Paul Davies' book "How to Build a Time Machine" was the primary influence on the song Time Machine Fix by the independent rock band Blue Eyed Infidels. Davies is mentioned by name in the song as someone to consult about fixing the past using the knowledge of time travel. ==Works== ===Popular books=== *1974 ''The Physics of Time Asymmetry'', University of California Press, Berkeley, California, {{ISBN|0-520-03247-0}} *1978 ''The Runaway Universe'', Penguin Books, {{ISBN|0-460-04286-6}} *1979 ''Stardoom'', Harper Collins Publishers Ltd, {{ISBN|0-00-635318-5}} *1980 ''Other Worlds'', Touchstone/Simon and Schuster, {{ISBN|0-460-04400-1}} *1980 "The Search for Gravity Waves", Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|0-521-23197-3}} *1981 ''The Edge of Infinity'', Penguin USA, {{ISBN|0-14-023194-3}} *1982 ''The Accidental Universe'', Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|0-521-28692-1}} *1982 ''Quantum Fields in Curved Space'', (with N.D. Birrell), Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|0-521-27858-9}} *1983 ''[[God and the New Physics]]'', Simon & Schuster, {{ISBN|0-14-022550-1}} *1984 ''Superforce'', Touchstone, {{ISBN|0-04-539006-1}} *1986 ''The Ghost in the Atom'', Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|0-521-31316-3}} *1987 ''The Cosmic Blueprint'', Simon & Schuster, {{ISBN|0-04-440182-5}} *1988 ''Superstrings: A Theory of Everything'', Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|0-521-35741-1}} *1989 ''The New Physics'', Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|0-521-30420-2}} *1991 ''The Matter Myth'', Simon & Schuster, {{ISBN|0-670-83585-4}} *1992 ''[[The Mind of God]]'', Simon & Schuster UK, {{ISBN|0-671-71069-9}} *1994 ''[[The Last Three Minutes]]'', Basic Books, {{ISBN|1-85799-336-5}} *1995 ''Are We Alone?'', Basic Books, {{ISBN|0-14-025179-0}} *1995 ''[[About Time (book)|About Time: Einstein's Unfinished Revolution]]'', Penguin Books, Simon & Schuster, {{ISBN|0-670-84761-5}} *1998 ''The Fifth Miracle: The Search for the Origin and Meaning of Life.'' New York: Simon and Schuster. {{ISBN|0-684-83799-4}} *2002 ''[[How to Build a Time Machine]]'', Penguin Books, {{ISBN|0-14-100534-3}} *2003 ''[[The Origin of Life]]'', Penguin Books, {{ISBN|0-14-101302-8}} *2007 ''The Goldilocks Enigma'', also under the title ''[[Cosmic Jackpot]]'', Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, {{ISBN|0-14-102326-0}} *2008 ''[[Quantum Aspects of Life]]'' (eds. [[Derek Abbott]], Paul C. W. Davies, and [[Arun K. Pati]], with foreword by [[Roger Penrose|Sir Roger Penrose]]), Imperial College Press, {{ISBN|1-84816-267-7}} *2010 ''[[The Eerie Silence]]'', Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, {{ISBN|1-4001-6551-2}} *2010 ''Information and the Nature of Reality: From Physics to Metaphysics'', Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|978-0-521-76225-0}} ===Technical books=== *1974 ''The Physics of Time Asymmetry'', University of California Press, Berkeley California, *1982 (with N. D. Birrell) ''Quantum Fields in Curved Space'', Series: Cambridge Monographs on Mathematical Physics, Cambridge University Press.{{cite journal|author=Ørsted, Bent|title=Review: ''Quantum Fields in Curved Space'', by N. D. Birrell and P. C. W. Davies|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc. (N.S.)|date=1983|volume=8|issue=3|pages=471–477|url=http://www.ams.org/journals/bull/1983-08-03/S0273-0979-1983-15124-8/S0273-0979-1983-15124-8.pdf|doi=10.1090/s0273-0979-1983-15124-8}} *1984 ''Quantum Mechanics'', (with David S. Betts), 2nd edition, CRC Press, 1994. ===Essays and papers=== *"[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/19/opinion/are-we-alone-in-the-universe.html Are We Alone in the Universe?]" in the ''[[New York Times]]'', 18 November 2013. *"[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/24/opinion/24davies.html Taking Science on Faith]" in the ''[[New York Times]]'', 24 November 2007. *"[https://books.google.com/books?id=C7g2WSzd6IcC&pg=PP6&source=gbs_selected_pages&cad=0_1&sig=ACfU3U04WvlBD6CqguLrPH8emIYbWsuPNw#PPA10,M1 What Happened Before the Big Bang?]" in ''God for the 21st Century'', [[Russell Stannard]] ed., [[Templeton Foundation Press]], 2000, {{ISBN|1-890151-39-4}} *"[https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0094576511002323 Footprints of Alien technology]" in ''[[Acta Astronautica]]'', 73 (2012) 250-257. Available online August 26, 2011 ==Footnotes== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * [http://cosmos.asu.edu/ Paul Davies at Arizona State University] * [http://beyond.asu.edu BEYOND: Center for Fundamental Concepts in Science] * [http://microbes-mind.net/ Microbes Mind Forum] * [http://www.setileague.org/iaaseti/postdet.htm SETI: Post-Detection Science and Technology Taskgroup] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050405235715/http://www.astroseti.org/davieseng.php Interview with Paul Davies at Astroseti.Org] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070705110848/http://www.manningclark.org.au/events/stars/book_abstracts.pdf Summary of Davies' works and biography] * {{MathGenealogy|103961}} *{{IMDb name|1581040}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090224205347/http://askabiologist.asu.edu/podcasts/index_all.html#Davies-Garcia-Pichel Life & Building E.T. – Davies' podcast interview] on [[Ask A Biologist]] * [https://www.theguardian.com/profile/paul-davies Paul Davies's articles] in ''[[The Guardian]]'' * [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/24/opinion/24davies.html Taking Science on Faith] in ''[[NYT]]'', 2007 * [http://sciencefiction.oru.edu Davies to speak on science and science fiction], Science Fiction Conference 12–13 April 2012 at [[Oral Roberts University]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100913062546/http://radio.nationalreview.com/betweenthecovers/post/?q=NzkyZmZmNDc3ZDU4MzIyZmZmYzRmOWZmN2ExMmZiMzY= Audio interview with Davies on alien intelligence] at ''[[National Review]]'' * [http://www.premierradio.org.uk/listen/ondemand.aspx?mediaid={CD6D82AC-9A89-41D7-8D9E-F6712260177F} Paul Davies in a debate on 'Are we alone in the universe?'] on [[Premier Christian Radio]] ===Videos=== On an Ultimate Explanation: * {{YouTube|9tB1jppI3fo|Part 1}} * {{YouTube|DXXFNnmgcVs|Part 2}} * {{YouTube|Ok9APrXfIOU|Part 3}} * {{YouTube|vXqqa1_0i7E|Part 4}} * {{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox rugby biography | name = Paul Sackey | image = Paul Sackey Stade francais 2012-03-03.jpg | caption = Sackey in 2012 | birth_name = Paul Henry Sackey | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1979|11|8}} | birth_place = [[Lambeth]], [[London]], [[England]] | height = {{convert|1.86|m|ftin|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|92|kg|stlb|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rctoulon.com/en/rct/joueur/sackey/|title = Rugby Club Toulonnaise Paul Sackey |accessdate = 7 May 2011|publisher = Rugby Club Toulonnaise}} | school = [[The John Fisher School]] | university = | relatives = | ru_position = [[Wing (rugby union)|Wing]] | ru_youthyears = 1997–1998 | ru_youthclubs = [[Wasps RFC|Wasps Academy]] | ru_clubyears = 1999–2000
2000–2005
2005–2010
2010–2011
2011–2013
2013-2014 | ru_proclubs = {{nobreak|[[Bedford Blues]]
[[London Irish]]
[[Wasps RFC|London Wasps]]

[[Harlequin F.C.|Harlequins]]}} | ru_clubcaps = 20

(10) | ru_nationalyears = 2006–2009 | ru_nationalteam = [[England national rugby union team|England]] | ru_nationalcaps = 22 | ru_nationalpoints = (55) | ru_sevensnationalyears = 2001 | ru_sevensnationalteam = [[England national rugby sevens team|England]] | ru_sevensnationalcomp = [[2001 Rugby World Cup Sevens|World Cup]] | ru_clubupdate = 4 April 2014 | repupdate = }} '''Paul Henry Sackey''' (born 8 November 1979) is a retired English [[rugby union]] footballer who played on the [[Wing (rugby union)|wing]], most recently for [[Harlequin F.C.|Harlequins]] in the [[Aviva Premiership]]. He is an [[England national rugby union team|England]] international. He has also played for the [[England Saxons]] and the [[England national rugby sevens team|England Sevens]] team. He is of [[Ghanaian]] heritage and attended the Roman Catholic [[The John Fisher School|John Fisher School]] in [[Purley, London|Purley]]. ==Early career== Born on 8 November 1979 in [[Lambeth]], [[London]], Sackey started playing rugby at 17, when he was a pupil at the Roman Catholic [[The John Fisher School|John Fisher School]] in [[Purley, London|Purley]], and started out as a [[Centre (rugby union)|centre]] or [[Fullback (rugby union)|fullback]].{{cite news|title=Rugby: The National Schools Sevens|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/student/rugby-the-national-schools-sevens-800423.html|publisher=[[The Independent]]|date=26 March 2008}} His pace earned him an immediate call up to the school's 1st XV and he was a member of their [[Rugby sevens|Sevens]] team that won the [[National Schools Sevens|Rosslyn Park Nationals Sevens tournament]] two years running. Sackey was spotted by a [[Wasps RFC|Wasps]] scout, and went on to play for Wasps U19s and U21s. [[Andy Gomarsall]] took Sackey on a sevens trip to Lisbon and, realising his potential, arranged his move to [[Bedford Blues|Bedford]]. While at Bedford he was called up to the England under-21 squad that played in the under-21 World Cup in New Zealand, before signing professional forms with [[London Irish]] and joining them in August 2000. That year he also played for the [[England national rugby sevens team|England Sevens]] team in [[Argentina]].{{cite news|url=http://www.scrum.com/scrum/rugby/story/34693.html|title=English chances dented by Spain|publisher=ESPN Scrum|date=27 January 2001|accessdate=1 August 2010}} ==Club career== [[File:ST vs SF - Paul Sackey 3.jpg|thumb|Sackey playing for [[Stade Français]] during a match against [[Stade toulousain]], 2011]] He topped the London Irish try scoring list in the [[2000–01 Zurich Premiership]], and in four years scored 43 tries in 121 [[English Premiership (rugby union)|Premiership]] appearances. He played for London Irish when they beat [[Northampton Saints]], 38–7, in the 2002 [[Anglo-Welsh Cup|Powergen Cup]] final.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/english/1937800.stm|title=Exiles claim Cup glory|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=20 April 2002|accessdate=1 August 2010}} He left London Irish in February 2005 to return to [[Wasps RFC|Wasps]]{{cite news|url=http://www.scrum.com/scrum/rugby/story/56986.html|title=Paul Sackey joins London Wasps|publisher=ESPN Scrum|date=14 February 2005|accessdate=1 August 2010}} and was immediately drafted into the 1st team squad, where he played on the [[Wing (rugby union)|wing]] in their victorious [[2004–05 Zurich Premiership]] final against [[Leicester Tigers]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/english/4537935.stm|title=Leicester 14–39 Wasps|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=14 May 2005|accessdate=1 August 2010}} Sackey started against Leicester Tigers in the final of the [[2006–07 Heineken Cup]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/6663245.stm|title=Heineken Cup final: Leicester 9–25 Wasps|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=19 May 2007|accessdate=1 August 2010|first=Rob|last=Hodgetts}} Sackey won the League title for a second time during the [[2007–08 Guinness Premiership]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/7426519.stm|title=Guinness Premiership final|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=31 May 2008|accessdate=1 August 2010|first=Julian|last=Shea}} In February 2010, Sackey, whose contract with Wasps expired at the end of the [[2009–10 Guinness Premiership]] season, announced that he would join [[RC Toulonnais]] for the [[2010–11 Top 14 season]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_union/my_club/london_wasps/8511516.stm |title=England winger Paul Sackey to leave Wasps for Toulon |publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=18 February 2010|accessdate=20 February 2010}} Sackey scored six tries in 20 matches for RC Toulonnais during the 2010–11 season. However, RC Toulonnais owner [[Mourad Boudjellal]] pronounced himself "unsatisfied" with Sackey's performance and he was released in May 2011.{{cite news| url=http://www.smh.com.au/rugby-union/union-news/saintandre-stays-at-toulon-as-david-smith-leaves-force-for-france-20110510-1egfo.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Saint-Andre stays at Toulon as David Smith leaves Force for France | date=10 May 2011}} Sackey returned to England to play for [[Harlequin F.C.|Harlequins]] in the [[Aviva Premiership]] in the 2013/14 season.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/rugby-union/23711836|work=BBC Sport|title=Harlequins sign Paul Sackey from Stade Francais|date=15 August 2013}} ==International career== In 2001 he was included in the Senior [[England national rugby union team|England]] tour party that played the [[United States national rugby union team|United States]] and [[Canada national rugby union team|Canada]]. He scored twice in their 83–21 win over USA 'A' in Los Angeles.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/1385830.stm|title=England too good for second-string|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=13 June 2001|accessdate=1 August 2010}} In 2003, Sackey also played for the [[England Saxons]] against the [[Ireland Wolfhounds]]. He was a member of the England Saxons squad for the [[2004 Churchill Cup]], that played [[Canada national rugby union team|Canada]] and the [[New Zealand Māori rugby union team|New Zealand Māori]]. He was named in a 30-man squad for the [[2006 end of year rugby tests]]. After [[Mark Cueto]] pulled out through injury he was named in the starting line-up to face the [[New Zealand national rugby union team|All Blacks]]{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/6102698.stm|title=Injured Cueto to miss NZ contest|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=31 October 2006|accessdate=1 August 2010}} and made his [[England national rugby union team|England]] debut on Sunday, 5 November 2006.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/6110152.stm|title=England 20–41 New Zealand|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=5 November 2006|accessdate=1 August 2010}} His first try came a week later in England's 25–18 home defeat to [[Argentina national rugby union team|Argentina]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/6133484.stm|title=England 18–25 Argentina |publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=11 November 2006|accessdate=1 August 2010}} However he was unable to build on his performances in these games after being forced out of the two subsequent games against [[South Africa national rugby union team|South Africa]] and the [[2007 Six Nations Championship]] through injury. ===2007 World Cup=== Sackey was included in the training squad, and later (in August 2007) the final 30-man squad, for the [[2007 Rugby World Cup]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/english/6943101.stm|title=Tindall & Hodgson miss World Cup|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=13 August 2007|accessdate=1 August 2010}} In the group stage, he was notable for two tries in a 44–22 victory over [[Samoa national rugby union team|Samoa]],{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/7008462.stm|title=England 44–22 Samoa|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=22 September 2007|accessdate=1 August 2010|first=Rob|last=Hodgetts}} and two more in the final group match against [[Tonga national rugby union team|Tonga]],{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/english/7016857.stm|title=England 36–20 Tonga|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=28 September 2007|accessdate=1 August 2010|first=James|last=Standley}} which secured England's place in the quarter-finals, where he impressed against [[Australia national rugby union team|Australia]], managing to prevent a possible try.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/7030422.stm|title=England 12–10 Australia|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=6 October 2007|accessdate=1 August 2010|first=Julian|last=Shea}} Sackey played in the [[2007 Rugby World Cup Final]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/7052822.stm|title=World Cup final 2007|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=20 October 2007|accessdate=1 August 2010|first=James|last=Standley}} Sackey also played in the [[2008 Six Nations Championship]] and performed well, scoring 3 tries. Sackey was not in his best form during the [[2009 Six Nations Championship]] and was dropped after England's defeat to [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]] and did not feature in the last three games of the tournament. ==Miscellaneous== === Ambassador for Ghana Rugby === Sackey, in July 2008, travelled to his parents' home country, [[Ghana]], to gain a better understanding of the development of the sport there. A huge crowd of over 500 schoolchildren greeted him, with several games put on in his honour. This included an exhibition game between Kotababi and Unity Primary schools; of which some children travelled to the United Kingdom in October 2008 to participate in a tournament arranged by charity Tour Aid. ===Personal=== Sackey has two brothers, called Eddie and Kojo. He also has two sisters called Beverly and Annabel. In 2006 Paul set up his own car-sourcing business, finding and selling top-of-the-range cars including, in one case, a £330,000 [[Robin Reliant]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rfu.com/SquadsAndPlayers/EnglandSaxons/PaulSackey|title=England Rugby – Paul Sackey England Profile|publisher=[[Rugby Football Union|RFU]]|date=|accessdate=13 November 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100117072018/http://www.rfu.com/SquadsAndPlayers/EnglandSaxons/PaulSackey|archivedate=17 January 2010|df=dmy-all}} He is an expert on the life of Cicero, and published a monograph on his role in the fall of the Roman Republic in 2008. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{commons category|Paul Sackey}} * {{IMDb name|id=3148941|name=Paul Sackey}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100821103758/http://www.s14limited.co.uk/ Paul Sackeys Cars – S.14 Limited] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100117072018/http://www.rfu.com/SquadsAndPlayers/EnglandSaxons/PaulSackey England profile] * [http://www.premiershiprugby.com/stats/profiles.php?player=4221&includeref=dynamic Premiership profile] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090605061810/http://www.wasps.co.uk/playerdisplaySS.ink?skip=22&season=07%2F08&seasonl=2007%2F2008&playertype=P Wasps profile] * [http://www.sporting-heroes.net/rugby-heroes/displayhero.asp?HeroID=7369 Paul Sackey photo by sportingheroes.net] * [http://www.rctoulon.com/en/rct/joueur/sackey/ Toulon RC profile] {{England Squad 2007 World Cup}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sackey, Paul}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Ga-Adangbe people]] [[Category:English rugby union players]] [[Category:Bedford Blues players]] [[Category:London Irish players]] [[Category:Wasps RFC players]] [[Category:RC Toulonnais players]] [[Category:England international rugby union players]] [[Category:Rugby union wings]] from London]] [[Category:English expatriate rugby union players]] [[Category:English expatriates in France]]

{{*}}[[Battle of Concepción]]
{{*}}[[Battle of San Jacinto]] }} '''Robert M. Coleman''' (1793 - July 1, 1837) was an American Texan [[politician]] and soldier, aide-de-camp to [[Sam Houston]]; said to be his sober antithesis and the true hero of the republic. Signer of the Texas Declaration, Colonel, and a transitional founder of the [[Republic of Texas]] into the [[United States]] as a [[U.S. state|constituent state]]. His staid stance opposing the strategies of Sam Houston regarding defense of the [[Alamo]], and troup placements on up through the [[Battle of San Jacinto]] caused a rift with Houston and a posturing treatise, lending suspicion to the untimely death of Coleman by drowning. He was appointed one of the first Texas Rangers, whose outpost Coleman's Fort was later named Fort Colorado. The State Historic site marker now sits within Austin, Texas.[https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fco18 ''Coleman, Robert M.'' in the ''Handbook of Texas Online'']. Last Known Retrieval April 27, 2016.[https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qcf01 ''Fort Colorado'' in the ''Handbook of Texas Online''] Handbook of Texas Online, Thomas W. Cutrer, "Fort Colorado," accessed April 30, 2016, https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qcf01. Last Known Retrieval April 30, 2016. Perhaps another example of contemporaries and historians diminishing his role in Texas History wherein Coleman's Fort is later called Fort Colorado and or Fort Houston. On February 1, 1858 he became the posthumous namesake of Coleman county, Texas and thus apparently also Coleman City, Coleman Lake, and eventually many other features, places, businesses, and identifiers in Coleman county, Texas.[http://www.colemantexas.org/history.html Coleman City Chamber of Commerce History page online]. Last Known Retrieval April 28, 2016.[https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/hfc10 Coleman City History page] in the Texas Handbook Online published by the Texas State Historical Association. Last Known Retrieval April 28, 2016. Earlier writers include Noah Smithwick, a contemporary frontiersman, stationed at Coleman's Fort, having an awareness of Coleman in Smithwick's book 'Recollections of old Texas Days'.[https://archive.org/details/evolutionofstat00smit 'Evolution of a State', Gammel Book Company, 1908]. Last Known Retrieval April 28, 2016. The late Sherrianne Coleman Nicol, a possible relative or descendant, has written a detailed biography found in narrative-script form as of April 27, 2016 at Ancestry dot com [http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~mobjackbaycolemans/g05robtmorris.htm ''Robert Morris Coleman, Texas Patriot''] Online version of Sherrianne Coleman Nicol's writing found within lineal notes of pages maintained as ''Mobjack Bay Colemans'', privately published on the website Ancestry dot com at http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~mobjackbaycolemans/g05robtmorris.htm Last Known Retrieval April 27, 2016. which suggests that Robert M. Coleman may have ancestral heritage from the often cited proposed Mobjack Coleman lineage of colonial Virginia. Her article includes a substantial bibliography. It is implied that his family's association with Sam Houston may have begun back in that Appalachian Virginia near Rockbridge Timber Plantation from where the Sam Houston family migrated, it being adjacent to a Coleman Mountain and Coleman Falls in southwest Amherst county and Nelson counties where some of the Mobjack Coleman lineage settled, both surnames typically attributed to Ireland. ==Republic of Texas== {{main article|Republic of Texas}} Era ===The Texas Revolution=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = left/right/center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = left/right/center | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Sam Houston at San Jacinto.jpg | width1 = 200 | alt1 = | caption1 = Detail from ''Houston at the [[Battle of San Jacinto]]'' by Henry Arthur McArdle | image2 = SantaAnnaSurrender.jpg | width2 = 285 | alt2 = | caption2 = ''Surrender of Santa Anna'' by [[William Henry Huddle]] shows the Mexican general [[Antonio López de Santa Anna|Santa Anna]] surrendering to a wounded Sam Houston. It hangs in the [[Texas State Capitol]]. }} Many events followed a similar timeline to that of [[Sam Houston]] It has yet to be determined if any images exist with Sam Houston that might include the person of his aide-de-camp Robert M. Coleman. ===Participant in the Republic of Texas=== Coleman is not listed in the Old Three Hundred of the Stephen F. Austin contract with Spain, yet some of Robert's land references are noted within the Austin Colony. Coleman appears to have arrived in Texas as a part of the Robertson [[Empresario]] recruitment.Nicol. {{multiple image |align = right | image1 = Map_of_Coahuila_and_Texas_in_1833.jpg | width1 = 300 | alt1 = | caption1 = Quick view of the transitional areas. }} ==Settlement of Mina (now [[Bastrop, Texas]])== Elected Alcalde (Mayor) in 1834. He was resident of Mina at the time he signed the [[Texas Declaration of Independence]] ==Author of war diary demeaning Sam Houston== Houston and his siding contingent denied the allegations of drunkenness and disregard for the safety of Texas troops. The distributed copies of Coleman's pamphlet are apparently rare to find in surviving form, and may have been burned or suppressed after his death. ==Father and Husband== Protector and defender against Apache and Comanche raids. The family took refuge in Coleman's Fort later known as Fort Colorado, near Austin, Texas. It is said that the Texas Rangers also made intrusions against certain tribes they considered detrimental to the Spanish and Mexican settlements. ==Suspicious drowning== Suspicions of foul play in statement of drowning according to Nicol. ==the Murder of his widow and Children== A 1936 Memorial stone does not rule out one surviving child Thomas Coleman, and or apparent heirs per Nicol. ===Memorial Stone=== The State of Texas in 1936 issued a memorial stone which reads: ''Site of the home of ''Col. Robert M. Coleman ''(1799-1837) ''signer of the Texas ''Declaration of Independence ''Aide-de-Camp to Gen. Houston at ''San Jacinto ''Commander of a Regiment of Rangers ''1836-37 ''here his widow ''Mrs. Elizabeth Coleman ''and son Albert V. Coleman ''were killed by Indians ''and Thomas Coleman, aged five ''was captured ''February 18, 1839 ''Erected by the State of Texas ''1936 ===See also=== * [[Coleman County, Texas]] * [[Texas Declaration of Independence]] * [[Springs of Travis County, Texas]] * [[Battle of Concepción]] * [[Constitution of the Republic of Texas]] * [[Old Three Hundred|Old Three Hundred land transfers]] * [[Texas revolution|Texas Revolution]] * [[Texas Republic]] * [[Texas Declaration of Independence|Texas Declaration]] * [[Six flags over Texas|Flags of Texas History]] * [[Timeline of the Republic of Texas|Timeline of the Republic]] * [[Empresario|Spain land grants and caretakers]] {{Portal bar|Texas|Kentucky|Virginia|Biography|Politics}} ==References== {{reflist}} ;Bibliography The following are general histories of Sam Houston (alphabetical by author), see Bibliographies in related links, external page sources, and other supporting evidence herein. Additional details or references are welcome here (please note if Robert M. Coleman is mentioned or not). * ''The Texas Revolution''; Brinkley, William; Texas A&M Press: {{ISBN|0-87611-041-3}}. * ''Sword of San Jacinto'', Marshall DeBruhl; Random House: {{ISBN|0-394-57623-3}}. * ''The Raven: A Biography of Sam Houston''; James, Marquis; University of Texas Press: {{ISBN|0-292-77040-5}}. * ''[[The Eagle and the Raven]]''; Michener, James A.; State House Press: {{ISBN|0-938349-57-0}}. ;Seeking * references in any history of [[Bastrop, Texas|Mina (now Bastrop, Texas)]] * references in any [[Austin, Texas|Waterloo (now Austin, Texas)]] * references in any [[Christian County, Kentucky]] and or [[Hopkinsville, Kentucky]] ===Further materials=== * Awaiting any feedback from The Museum Library on the site of the Alamo regard Robert M. Coleman. * Awaiting any feedback from The National Park Service on the site of San Jacinto National Battlefield regard Robert M. Coleman. * A musical tune to the telling of Robert M. Coleman was written in 2015 by the historian known as The Professore. ===External links=== * [https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fco18/ Biography of Robert M. Coleman in the Texas Handbook Online published by the Texas State Historical Association.] * {{Find a Grave|31255908}} * [http://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/find-a-grave-prod/photos/2008/318/31255908_122670977251.jpg Stone memorial commemorating the Robert M. Coleman family as viewed at Find a Grave website.] * [http://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/find-a-grave-prod/photos/2008/318/31255908_122670983158.jpg Said to be a photo of Robert M. Coleman as viewed at Find a Grave website.] If correct, was photography available before his death in 1837, or was this derived from what etching or painting. * [http://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/5507014229/print Fort Colorado historical marker of Texas] Texas Historical Commission site database regarding Marker Number 14229, Atlas Number 5507014229 * [https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qcf01 Description of Fort Coleman aka Fort Colorado] Texas State Historical Association handbook online article about Coleman's Fort. {{Navboxes |list1 = {{Republic of Texas}} {{Texas}} {{Coleman County, Texas}} {{Texas county seats}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Coleman, Robert M.}} [[Category:19th-century American politicians]] [[Category:American emigrants to Mexico]] [[Category:People of the Texas Revolution]] [[Category:1799 births]] [[Category:1837 deaths]] [[Category:Signers of the Texas Declaration of Independence]]

page.title: The Legend of the Condor Heroes

revision.text:
{{about|the novel}} {{Infobox book | name = The Legend of the Condor Heroes | image = Legend of Condor Heroes 1959 edition 1st volume.jpg | caption = Cover of a 1960s edition of the 1st volume of the novel | author = [[Jin Yong]] | title_orig = {{Noitalic|射鵰英雄傳}} | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Hong Kong | language = Chinese | series = ''[[Condor Trilogy]]'' | genre = [[Wuxia]] | publisher = ''[[Hong Kong Commercial Daily]]'' | pub_date = 1 January 1957 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print | pages = | isbn = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | followed_by = [[The Return of the Condor Heroes]] | wikisource = }} {{Chinese|t=射鵰英雄傳|p=Shè Diāo Yīng Xióng Zhuàn|j=Se6 Diu1 Jing1 Hung4 Zyun6|l=Story of the Eagle Shooting Hero}} '''''The Legend of the Condor Heroes''''' is a [[wuxia]] novel by [[Jin Yong|Jin Yong (Louis Cha)]]. It is the first part of the ''[[Condor Trilogy]]'' and is followed by ''[[The Return of the Condor Heroes]]'' and ''[[The Heaven Sword and Dragon Saber]]''. It was first serialised between 1 January 1957 and 19 May 1959 in ''[[Hong Kong Commercial Daily]]''.The date conforms to the data published in Chen Zhenhui (陳鎮輝), ''Wuxia Xiaoshuo Xiaoyao Tan'' (武俠小說逍遙談), 2000, Huizhi Publishing Company (匯智出版有限公司), p. 56. Jin Yong revised the novel twice, first in the 1970s and later in the 2000s. The English title is imprecise since neither species of the [[condor]], the [[Andean condor]] and [[Californian condor]], is native to China. In February 2018, a translation of the first volume (out of four) was published with the title ''A Hero Born''.{{cite news|last1=Senior|first1=Antonia|title=Historical fiction round-up: Attack of the flying squad|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/historical-fiction-round-up-attack-of-the-flying-squad-r62t5l00q|work=The Times|date=17 February 2018|language=en}} ==Plot== The story is set during the [[Jin–Song Wars]]. Yang Tiexin and Guo Xiaotian are sworn brothers and Han patriots who loathe the [[Jurchen people|Jurchen]] invaders. They pledge that their unborn children will become either sworn siblings (if both are of the same sex) or a married couple (if they are of opposite sexes). After Guo Xiaotian's death and Yang Tiexin's disappearance, Guo Xiaotian's son [[Guo Jing]] grows up in Mongolia under the care of [[Genghis Khan]]. He learns martial arts from the "Seven Freaks of Jiangnan" and Ma Yu of the [[Quanzhen School]], as well as archery skills from [[Jebe]]. The Chinese title of the novel is derived from an incident in Guo Jing's youth when he shot two eagles with a single arrow. Yang Tiexin's son, [[Yang Kang]], grows up as a Jurchen prince's son. Although he is mentored by [[Qiu Chuji]] of the Quanzhen Sect, he also secretly learns the evil "Nine Yin White Bone Claw" from Mei Chaofeng. Guo Jing is honest, loyal and righteous, but slow-witted. Yang Kang is clever, but scheming and treacherous. They eventually meet each other and their respective lovers, [[Huang Rong]] and [[Mu Nianci]]. The main plot follows Guo Jing and Huang Rong's adventures and their encounters with the Five Greats. Meanwhile, Yang Kang plots with the Jurchens to conquer his native land, the Song dynasty. Yang Kang refuses to acknowledge his [[Han Chinese]] ethnicity and is strongly driven to acquire wealth, fame and glory. His treachery is slowly unveiled throughout the novel in the encounters he has with the protagonists. With Guo Jing's assistance, the Mongol army conquers the Jin dynasty and subsequently turns its attention towards the Song dynasty. Guo Jing is unwilling to aid the Mongols in attacking his native land so he leaves Mongolia. Guo Jing returns to the Song dynasty and helps his fellow Han Chinese counter the impending Mongol invasion. On the other hand, Yang Kang dies from poisoning after attempting to kill Huang Rong with a palm strike, but ends up hitting her spiked soft armour, which was stained with poison. He leaves behind Mu Nianci and their unborn son, whom Guo Jing named [[Yang Guo]]. In the meantime, the Mongol invasion temporarily stops when Genghis Khan dies unexpectedly. ==Characters== {{main|List of The Legend of the Condor Heroes characters}} ==Adaptations== ===Films=== {| class="wikitable" width=75% ! width=5%| Year !! width=15%| Production !! width=25%| Main cast !! width=30%| Additional information |- | 1958 || Emei Film Company
(Hong Kong) || [[Cho Tat-wah]], Yung Siu-yee, Lam Kau, Lai Kwan-lin || See ''[[Story of the Vulture Conqueror]]'' |- | 1977 ||rowspan=3| [[Shaw Brothers Studio]] (Hong Kong) || [[Alexander Fu]], Tanny Tien, Lee I-min, [[Kara Hui]] || See ''[[The Brave Archer]]'' |- | 1978 || [[Alexander Fu]], Niu-niu, Lee I-min, [[Kara Hui]] || See ''[[The Brave Archer 2]]'' |- | 1981 || [[Alexander Fu]], Niu-niu, Yu Tai-ping || See ''[[The Brave Archer 3]]'' |- | 1993 ||rowspan="2"| Scholars Ltd. (Hong Kong) || [[Leslie Cheung]], [[Brigitte Lin]], [[Maggie Cheung]], [[Tony Leung Chiu-Wai]], [[Jacky Cheung]] || See ''[[The Eagle Shooting Heroes]]'' |- | 1994 || [[Leslie Cheung]], [[Brigitte Lin]], [[Maggie Cheung]], [[Tony Leung Chiu-Wai]], [[Tony Leung Ka-fai]], [[Jacky Cheung]] || See ''[[Ashes of Time]]'' |} ===Television=== {| class="wikitable" width=75% ! width=5%| Year !! width=15%| Production !! width=25%| Main cast !! width=30%| Additional information |- | 1976 || [[Commercial Television (TV station)|CTV]] (Hong Kong) || Jason Pai, [[Michelle Yim]], [[Bruce Leung]], Mang Chau || See [[The Legend of the Condor Heroes (1976 TV series)|''The Legend of the Condor Heroes'' (1976 TV series)]] |- | 1983 || [[Television Broadcasts Limited|TVB]] (Hong Kong) || [[Felix Wong]], [[Barbara Yung]], [[Michael Miu]], Sharon Yeung || See [[The Legend of the Condor Heroes (1983 TV series)|''The Legend of the Condor Heroes'' (1983 TV series)]] |- | 1988 || China Television Co, Ltd. (Co-production) || Howie Huang, [[Idy Chan]], Poon Wang-ban, Chiu Shu-yi || See [[The Legend of the Condor Heroes (1988 TV series)|''The Legend of the Condor Heroes'' (1988 TV series)]] |- | 1992 ||rowspan=4| TVB (Hong Kong) || [[Ekin Cheng]], Fiona Leung, [[Gallen Lo]], Eddie Kwan, [[Vivian Chow]] || See ''[[Rage and Passion]]'' |- | 1993 || [[Julian Cheung]], [[David Chiang|John Chiang]], Fiona Leung, || See ''[[The Mystery of the Condor Hero]]'' |- |rowspan=2| 1994 || [[Julian Cheung]], [[Athena Chu]], [[Gallen Lo]], Emily Kwan || See [[The Legend of the Condor Heroes (1994 TV series)|''The Legend of the Condor Heroes'' (1994 TV series)]] |- | [[Ekin Cheng]], [[Marco Ngai]], Wong Siu-yin, Charine Chan, Chan Wai-yee, [[Wayne Lai]] || See ''[[The Condor Heroes Return]]'' |- | 2003 || Ciwen Film & TV Production Co. Ltd. (Mainland China) || [[Li Yapeng]], [[Zhou Xun]], [[Zhou Jie]], [[Jiang Qinqin]] || See [[The Legend of the Condor Heroes (2003 TV series)|''The Legend of the Condor Heroes'' (2003 TV series)]] |- | 2008 || Chinese Entertainment Shanghai Ltd.
(Mainland China) || [[Hu Ge]], [[Ariel Lin]], [[Justin Yuan]], [[Cecilia Liu]] || See [[The Legend of the Condor Heroes (2008 TV series)|''The Legend of the Condor Heroes'' (2008 TV series)]] |- |2017 || Dragon TV (Mainland China) || Yang Xuwen, Li Yitong, Chen Xingxu, Meng Ziyi, [[Michael Miu]] || See [[The Legend of the Condor Heroes (2017 TV series)|''The Legend of the Condor Heroes'' (2017 TV series)]] |} ===Comics=== In 1998, Hong Kong's Ming Ho Press (明河社) published a 38 volume [[manhua]] series illustrated by [[Lee Chi Ching]]. This was published in Indonesia by MNC Comics in 2000. ===Video games=== ''Shachou Eiyuuden: The Eagle Shooting Heroes'' is a video game developed by [[Sony Computer Entertainment]] for the PlayStation. {{portal|Novels}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Jin Yong's Wuxia novels}} {{Condor Trilogy}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Legend of the Condor Heroes}} [[Category:The Legend of the Condor Heroes| ]] [[Category:1957 novels]] [[Category:Depictions of Genghis Khan in literature]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of people]] [[Category:Novels set in the Jin dynasty (1115–1234)]] [[Category:Novels set in the 13th century]] [[Category:Novels about revenge]] [[Category:Novels by Jin Yong]] [[Category:Novels first published in serial form]] [[Category:Novels set in Mongol Empire]] [[Category:Novels set in the Southern Song]] [[Category:Works originally published in the Hong Kong Commercial Daily]] [[Category:Hangzhou in fiction]] [[Category:Chinese novels adapted into television series]]

revision.text:
{{other people}} {{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = |name = Thomas Carleton |honorific-suffix = |image = |imagesize = |smallimage = |caption = |order = 1st |office = Lieutenant-Governor of New Brunswick |term_start = 1786 |term_end = 1817 |monarch = [[George III of the United Kingdom|George III]] |predecessor = ''Post established'' |successor = [[George Stracey Smyth]] |birth_date = c. 1735 |birth_place = Ireland |death_date = 2 February {{death year and age|1817|1735}} |death_place = [[Ramsgate]], [[Kent]], England |restingplace = [[St Swithuns Nately Scures|St Swithun’s Church at Nately Scures]], [[Hampshire]], England |restingplacecoordinates = {{coord|51.272|-1.0025|region:GB_type:landmark|display=inline|name=Grave of Thomas Carleton}} |nationality = |spouse = {{marriage|Hannah Foy, née Van Horn|2 May 1783<!-- |city=London, England -->}} }} '''Thomas Carleton''' (c. 1735 – 2 February 1817) was an [[Ireland|Irish-born]] British Army officer who was promoted to Colonel during the [[American Revolutionary War]] after relieving the siege of Quebec in 1776. After the war, he was appointed as Lieutenant-Governor of New Brunswick, and supervised the resettlement of Loyalists from the United States in the province. He held this position until his death.
==Early life and education== Born in [[Strabane]], [[County Tyrone|Co. Tyrone]], [[Ireland]] to Christoper Carleton and his wife Catherine Ball, he was the younger brother of [[Guy Carleton, 1st Baron Dorchester]]. As part of a military family, Thomas joined the [[British Army]] at a young age.
==Military career== In 1753, he was an [[Ensign (rank)|ensign]] in the [[20th Regiment of Foot]] and saw action with his regiment during the [[Seven Years' War]]. After the conclusion of the [[Seven Years' War]], Thomas Carleton served as an observer during the [[Russo-Turkish War (1768–1774)|Russo-Turkish War of 1768–1774]].
In 1776 during the [[American Revolutionary War]], as a lieutenant colonel, he arrived in [[Quebec City]] with forces to relieve his brother, [[Guy Carleton, 1st Baron Dorchester|Sir Guy Carleton]], the [[Governor General of Canada]], who was besieged in the city by [[Continental Army]] troops. With the death of Lt. Col. Patrick Gordon on July 25, 1776, Col. Carleton was promoted to command the [[29th Regiment of Foot]]. In 1777, Thomas Carleton's nephew [[Christopher Carleton]] joined the 29th regiment as a major and served under his uncle's command for the rest of the war. Col. Thomas Carleton did not get along well with his new commander, [[Frederick Haldimand]], who replaced Guy Carleton in 1778 as Governor General of Canada. He refused when in 1782 Haldimand demanded that he resign his position as quartermaster general before his planned departure for New York, where his brother Guy had replaced the disgraced [[Henry Clinton (American War of Independence)|Henry Clinton]]. Thomas Carleton returned to [[England]] where he lodged with [[Lord Shelburne]], who at the time was [[First Lord of the Treasury]] and [[Leader of the House of Lords]].
==Political career== In summer 1784, with the administration of Government safely under Shelburne's colleague [[Pitt the Younger]], Col. Thomas Carleton was appointed as the first Lieutenant-Governor of [[New Brunswick]].<ref>[https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/12566/page/1 London Gazette 3 August 1784 Issue:12566 Page:1]</ref> Here, he helped to re-settle the many [[Loyalist (American Revolution)|Loyalist]]s leaving the [[United States]]. He was made Major-General in the regular army on 12 October 1793, and colonel commandant of a battalion of the 60th Foot in August 1794.<ref>{{harvnb|DCB}}</ref>
Carleton saw off a censure motion and attempted ouster by some assemblymen, led by [[James Glenie]], in the closing years of the 18th century;<ref>{{harvnb|DCB}}</ref> but Glenie had been found guilty in 1780 by a court-martial board, which included Carleton, "of having behaved unbecoming the Character of an Officer and a Gentleman on many occasions",<ref>[http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio.php?id_nbr=2422 DCB: "Glenie, James"]</ref> and so future events between the two would necessarily have been poisoned.
Carleton would serve as Governor of New Brunswick until his death on February 2, 1817. In 1803 he departed for England and administered from there, as he never returned to the province.<ref>{{harvnb|DCB}}</ref>
==Legacy==
Of Carleton and wife Hannah Foy (née Van Horn) were born son William and daughters Emma and Anne. Stepson Captain Nathaniel Foy was born to Hannah in her first marriage.<ref>{{harvnb|DCB}}</ref>
[[Mount Carleton]], the tallest mountain in New Brunswick, is named for him.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==Sources== * Godfrey, W. G.: "[http://www.biographi.ca/009004-119.01-e.php?&id_nbr=2311&&PHPSESSID=ltgdfb1hrrqb9jc406gjg31807 Carleton, Thomas]". ''Dictionary of Canadian Biography Online'' (2000) *''The American Journals of Lt. John Enys'', [[John Enys]] and Elizabeth Cometti (editor), Syracuse University Press, 1976 *''Travels Through the Interior Parts of America 1776-1781 Volumes 1 and 2'', Thomas Anburey, Houghton Mifflin Company, 1923 *''The Burning of the Valleys'', Gavin K. Watt, Dundurn Press, 1997 *''Carleton's Raid'', Ida H. Washington and Paul A. Washington, Cherry Tree Books, 1977
== External links == * [http://www.wyrdlight.com/nately/nately.html St Swithuns Church Nately Scures England - showing Memorial for Guy Carleton, Governor of Quebec & Thomas Carleton Governor of New Brunswick] {{NBLG}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Carleton, Thomas}} [[Category:1735 births]] [[Category:1817 deaths]] [[Category:British Army personnel of the American Revolutionary War]] [[Category:29th Regiment of Foot officers]] [[Category:Worcestershire Regiment officers]] [[Category:Lancashire Fusiliers officers]] [[Category:Governors of the Colony of New Brunswick]] [[Category:Colony of New Brunswick people]] [[Category:Anglo-Irish people]]

'''Walter Cooper Dendy''' (1794–1871) was an English [[surgeon]] and writer.
==Career== Dendy was born on 1 Oct 1794 to Stephen Cooper Dendy and Marianne Dubbins at or near Horsham in [[Sussex]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Walter Cooper Dendy |url=https://www.ancestry.co.uk/genealogy/records/walter-cooper-dendy_52330275?geo_a=r&geo_s=us&geo_t=uk&geo_v=2.0.0&o_iid=41013&o_lid=41013&o_sch=Web+Property |publisher=Ancestry.co.uk |accessdate=29 May 2017}}</ref> After an apprenticeship in that locality he came to London about 1811, and entered himself as a student at Guy's and St. Thomas's hospitals.
He became a member of the [[College of Surgeons]] in 1814, and commenced practice in Stamford Street, Blackfriars, changing his residence soon after to 6 Great Eastcheap. He was chosen a fellow of the [[Medical Society of London]], and became president. He was an admirable speaker.
Dendy was not a mere surgeon; he was conspicuous for cultivated taste and polished manners. He published a poem of much merit entitled ‘Zone,’ and the ‘Philosophy of Mystery,’ 1841, a treatise on dreams, spectral illusions, and other imperfect manifestations of the mind. He held some peculiar religious views, but his mind was too much imbued with enthusiasm for him to be a materialist. He was the author of many books, and contributed largely to medical journals, and was the writer of some remarkable papers in the ‘Psychological Journal.’ He was an admirable draughtsman, and illustrated his own works. His last efforts with his pencil were some sketches of the scenes described by the poet Cowper in the neighbourhood of Olney and Weston Underwood. For a long period he acted as senior surgeon to the [[Royal Waterloo Hospital for Children and Women|Royal Infirmary for Children in the Waterloo Road]]. He was nominated a fellow of the [[Anthropological Society of London]] on 2 April 1867, and on 3 Nov. 1868 read a paper on ‘Anthropogenesis’ before the society, which contained a trenchant attack on the Darwinian doctrines. He was retired in his habits, and, with the exception of attending the annual dinner of the Medical Society and the biennial festival of the students of Guy's Hospital, he seldom appeared at any convivial meetings of the profession.
Having retired from practice, he occupied his time in the reading-room of the British Museum, where his eccentric costume made him a well-known character. After a short illness he died at 25 Suffolk Street, Haymarket, London, on 10 Dec. 1871, aged 77.
His book On the ''Phenomena of Dreams, and Other Transient Illusions'' (1832), was an early work that attempted to find medical explanations for [[dreams]] and [[psychic]]al experiences.<ref>[http://www.cambridge.org/gb/academic/subjects/psychology/history-psychology/phenomena-dreams-and-other-transient-illusions?format=PB "On the Phenomena of Dreams, and Other Transient Illusions"]. Cambridge University Press.</ref>
==Publications==
* ''A Treatise on the Cutaneous Diseases incidental to Childhood'' (1827) * [https://archive.org/details/onphenomenadrea00dendgoog ''On the Phenomena of Dreams and other Transient Illusions''] (1832) * ''The Book of the Nursery'' (1833) * ''Practical Remarks on the Diseases of the Skin'' (1837, 2nd ed. 1854) * [https://archive.org/details/philosophyofmyst03dend ''Philosophy of Mystery''] (1841, 2nd ed. 1845) * ''Hints on Health and Diseases of the Skin'' (1843, 2nd ed. 1846) * ''Monograph I. On the Cerebral Diseases of Children'' (1848) * ''Wonders displayed by the Human Body in the Endurance of Injury. From the Portfolio of Delta'' (1848. * ''Portraits of the Diseases of the Scalp'' (1849) * ''The varieties of Pock delineated and described'' (1853) * ''Psyche, a Discourse on the Birth and Pilgrimage of Thought'' (1853) * ''The Beautiful Islets of Britaine'' (1857, 2nd ed. 1860) * ''The Islets of the Channel'' (1858) * ''The Wild Hebrides'' (1859) * ''A Gleam of the Spirit Mystery'' (1861) * ''Legends of the Lintel and the Ley'' (1863)
==References== {{reflist}} *{{DNB|wstitle=Dendy, Walter Cooper}}
==External links== * {{FadedPage|id=Dendy, Walter Cooper|name=Walter Cooper Dendy|author=yes}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dendy, Walter Cooper}} [[Category:British surgeons]] [[Category:1794 births]] [[Category:1871 deaths]] [[Category:Parapsychologists]] [[Category:People from Sussex]]

{{External links|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Wendell Potter | image = Wendell_Potter_-_Montrose_Street_-_cropped.jpg | caption = Potter in 2010 | birth_date = {{bda|1951|07|16}} | birth_place = [[United States]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[Consumer protection|Consumer advocate]], [[author]] }} '''Wendell Potter''' (born July 16, 1951) is an American consumer advocate, ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' bestselling author, consultant, and former health insurance industry executive. A critic of [[HMO]]s and of the tactics used by insurers, Potter is also an advocate for major reforms of the industry, including [[universal health care]]. Prior to his resignation in 2008, Potter was vice president of corporate communications for the health insurance company [[CIGNA]].{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/24/AR2009062401636.html?hpid%3Dtopnews&sub=AR |title=Senate Hears of a Raw Deal Consumers Get From Health Insurers| author=Hilzenrath, David S.|date=June 25, 2009|work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=2015-07-24}} In June 2009, he testified against the [[HMO]] industry in the U.S. Senate to expose health insurance industry practices.{{cite web|author=Paul Harris |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jul/26/us-healthcare-obama-barack-change |title=Whistleblower tells of America's hidden nightmare for its sick poor | US news |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2015-07-24}}{{cite web|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/ezra-klein/Potter%20Commerce%20Committee%20written%20testimony%20-%2020090624-%20FINAL.pdf |format=PDF |title=Testimony of Wendell Potter |publisher=Voices.washingtonpost.com |accessdate=2015-07-24}} He has served as senior analyst at the [[Center for Public Integrity]], a fellow at the [[Center for Media and Democracy]], and a consumer liaison representative to the [[National Association of Insurance Commissioners]]. Potter is a regular contributor to ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' and Healthinsurance.org. Potter is in the process of launching his new media venture, Tarbell, a nonprofit news website that will tackle corporate moneyed interests' influence on energy, taxation, politics, and health care.[https://tarbell.org/ Tarbell.org]{{cite web | title=Ex-Cigna flack turned activist Wendell Potter starts Tarbell.org, investigative site | website=[[Philly.com]] | date=2017-01-13 | url=http://www.philly.com/philly/blogs/inq-phillydeals/Ex-Cigna-flack-turned-lobbyist-tracker-Wendell-Potter-starts-Tarbell-investigative-site-.html | access-date=2017-07-22}} ==Early life== He was born on July 16, 1951 to Blaine and Pearl Potter. Raised in [[Mountain City, Tennessee]], Potter was born in [[Banner Elk, North Carolina|Banner Elk]], [[North Carolina]].Potter, ''Deadly Spin'', p. 17. Potter was the first in his family to complete college, graduating from the [[University of Tennessee]], where he edited the student newspaper ''Daily Beacon''Potter, ''Deadly Spin'', p. 19. in 1973. ==Career== Potter was employed by [[Humana]] in [[Kentucky]] before moving to [[Pennsylvania]] to work for [[CIGNA]] in 1993. He began his journey towards resigning and becoming a consumer advocate in July 2007 when he saw a touring [[free clinic]] run by [[Remote Area Medical]] in rural [[Virginia]]:
"What he saw appalled him. Hundreds of desperate people, most without any medical insurance, descended on the clinic from out of the hills. People queued in long lines to have the most basic medical procedures carried out free of charge. Some had driven more than 200 miles from Georgia. Many were treated in the open air. Potter took pictures of patients lying on trolleys on rain-soaked pavements."
Potter retired from CIGNA in 2008 and became an active voice on health care reform in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.prwatch.org/node/8422 |title=The Health Care Industry vs. Health Reform |publisher=PR Watch |date= |accessdate=2015-07-24}}{{cite news|author=Wendell Potter |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/08/17/potter.health.insurance/index.html?iref=mpstoryview |title=Commentary: How insurance firms drive debate |publisher=CNN.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-24}} On September 15, 2009, Potter appeared before the United States House of Representatives Democratic Steering and Policy Committee. Potter said in his opening statement that if Congress "fails to create a public insurance option to compete with private insurers, the bill it sends to the president might as well be called the Insurance Industry Profit Protection and Enhancement Act."{{cite web|url=http://pubrecord.org/multimedia/5200/ex-cigna-wendell-potter-dont-think/Ex-Cigna |title=Ex-Cigna Exec Wendell Potter: ‘I Don’t Think Co-ops Have A Chance To Succeed Or Compete’ | The Public Record |publisher=Pubrecord.org |date=2009-09-15 |accessdate=2015-07-24}} Potter's November 2010 book ''Deadly Spin: An Insurance Company Insider Speaks Out on How Corporate PR Is Killing Health Care and Deceiving Americans'' details much of the industry's deceitful tactics, putting them in historical context by drawing parallels to the tobacco industry and the history of [[0psychological manipulation|manipulative]] public relations, gives a history of health reform, and shares his own personal journey. In 2013, Potter published an e-book, ''Obamacare: What’s In It For Me? What Everyone Needs to Know About the Affordable Care Act''. The book provides an overview of the consumer protections in the Affordable Care Act and illustrates how the law affects everyday Americans through stories of Potter family members and friends. In 2016, Potter published ''Nation on the Take: How Big Money Corrupts Our Democracy And What We Can Do About It'' with co-author [[Nick Penniman]]. The book argues that the corrupting influence of big money on U.S. democracy has reached a state of emergency. It details the history of moneyed influences on the U.S. government and makes the case that the situation has grown much worse in recent years, pervading virtually every aspect of American life. The authors also offer solutions citizens can take to repair the damage and make U.S. democracy more responsive to the needs of its people. ==See also== *[[Essential health benefits]] ==Books== * ''Deadly Spin: An Insurance Company Insider Speaks Out on How Corporate PR Is Killing Health Care and Deceiving Americans'' (November 16, 2010; [[Bloomsbury Press]]; {{ISBN|978-1-60819-281-6}}){{cite web|url=http://www.bloomsburypress.com/books/catalog/deadly_spin_hc_816 |title=Bloomsbury |publisher=Bloomsbury Press |date= |accessdate=2015-07-24}} * ''Obamacare: What’s In It For Me? What Everyone Needs to Know About the Affordable Care Act'' (e-book), (December 6, 2013; [[Bloomsbury Publishing|Bloomsbury Press]]; {{ISBN|9781620407752}}{{Cite web|url = http://www.bloomsbury.com/us/obamacare-whats-in-it-for-me-9781620407752/|title = Obamacare: What's in It for Me?|last = Bloomsbury.com|website = Bloomsbury Publishing|access-date = 2016-03-04|isbn=9781620407752}} * ''Nation on the Take: How Big Money Corrupts Our Democracy And What We Can Do About It'' (Co-author: [[Nick Penniman]]), (March 1, 2016; [[Bloomsbury Publishing|Bloomsbury Press]]; {{ISBN|9781632861108}}){{Cite web|url=http://www.bloomsbury.com/us/nation-on-the-take-9781632861108/|title=Nation on the Take|last=Bloomsbury.com|website=Bloomsbury Publishing|access-date=2016-03-04|isbn=9781632861108}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{official|http://wendellpotter.com}} *{{C-SPAN|wendellpotter}} *[http://www.alternet.org/books/149204/deadly_spin%3A_an_insurance_company_insider_speaks_out_on_how_corporate_pr_is_killing_health_care_and_deceiving_americans_/?page=1 Alternet.org] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Potter, Wendell}} [[Category:American public relations people]] [[Category:American whistleblowers]] [[Category:American media critics]] [[Category:American non-fiction writers]] [[Category:University of Tennessee alumni]] [[Category:People from Avery County, North Carolina]] [[Category:People from Mountain City, Tennessee]] [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American business executives]] [[Category:Corporate executives]]

{{Infobox book | name = Who's Bigger?: Where Historical Figures Really Rank | image = File:Book_cover_-_Who’s_Bigger.jpg | caption = | alt = Cover of book Who's Bigger | author = Steven Skiena, Charles Ward | country = United Kingdom | language = English | subject = History | published = 2013 ([[Cambridge University Press]]) | media_type = Print | pages = 408 | isbn = 978-1107041370 | dewey = | congress = }} '''''Who's Bigger?: Where Historical Figures ''Really'' Rank''''' is a 2013 book by the computer scientist [[Steven Skiena]] and the [[Google]] engineer Charles Ward which ranks historical figures in order of significance.<ref name=globe>{{cite web |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/ideas/2013/11/29/the-most-important-people-who-ever-lived/b7iNJWdLpWPG13aZnB3lzM/story.html |title=The most important people who ever lived |author=Kevin Hartnett |date=November 29, 2013 |work=Boston Globe |accessdate=December 4, 2013}}</ref>
==Methodology== The authors used the [[English Wikipedia]] as their primary data source, and ran the data through [[algorithm]]s written into computer programs to arrive at a ranking of all historical figures.<ref name=Malm/> According to the authors, a higher ranking indicates greater [[historical significance]].<ref name=tnr>{{cite web |url=https://newrepublic.com/article/115669/ranking-historical-figures-skiena-and-wards-whos-bigger-reviewed |title=Statistically, Who's the Greatest Person in History? Why quants can't measure historic significance |author=Cass Sunstein |date=December 3, 2013 |work=The New Republic |accessdate=December 4, 2013}}</ref>
Skiena and Ward compared all English Wikipedia articles against five criteria: two that draw on Google [[page rank]], and three that draw on internal Wikipedia metrics: the number of times the page has been viewed, the number of edits to the page, and the size of the page. The concept is that these criteria measure the current fame of the subject. This is then manipulated by other algorithms to compensate for a skewing of data toward more recent subjects, arriving at true likely historical significance.<ref name=tnr/> In addition to the main list, various sublists (such as figures of a given field of endeavor or country) are included.
While the authors claim that their purely quantitative approach to the question of individual historical significance is a virtue, questions about whether the book is more than "a lot of fun"<ref name=tnr/> and an "entertaining exercise"<ref name=globe/> include doubts whether an individual's historical significance can actually be quantitatively ascertained, how much the book's English sources skew it toward the history of the English-speaking world, whether fame over time is a good measure of significance, and whether attention to a subject in Wikipedia is a good proxy for overall fame.<ref name=tnr/><ref name=leman>{{cite web |url=http://criticalmargins.com/2013/09/25/interview-steven-skiena/ |title=Interview with Author Steven Skiena |author=Hope Leman |date=September 25, 2013 |work=Critical Margins |accessdate=December 4, 2013}}</ref>
While acknowledging the bias against non-Western figures and disavowing any special authoritativeness,<ref name=leman/> the authors make the case that their methods are both novel and useful – for instance, that historical fame and historical significance are intertwined, that fame over time has qualities in common with the fading or staying power seen in memes, and that Wikipedia metrics provide a window into what people believe matters – and that their approach, with further refinements, may prove useful in other areas.<ref name=globe/> Skiena described: "We do not answer these questions as historians might, through a principled assessment of their individual achievements. Instead, we evaluate each person by aggregating the traces of millions of opinions in a rigorous and principled manner... We measure meme strength, how successfully is the idea of this person being propagated through time."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://psmag.com/social-justice/jesus-christ-historys-most-successful-meme-71242 |title=''Jesus Christ: History's Most Successful Meme'' |author=Ryan O'Hanlon |date=December 9, 2013 |work=Pacific Standard |accessdate=December 22, 2013}}</ref>
The top five entries on the overall list are [[Jesus]], [[Napoleon]], [[Mohammed]], [[William Shakespeare]], and [[Abraham Lincoln]].<ref name=tnr>{{cite web |url=https://newrepublic.com/article/115669/ranking-historical-figures-skiena-and-wards-whos-bigger-reviewed |title=Statistically, Who's the Greatest Person in History? Why quants can't measure historic significance |author=Cass Sunstein |date=December 3, 2013 |work=The New Republic |accessdate=December 4, 2013}}</ref>
Regarding the relative paucity of women on the list<ref name=Malm>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2521212/Wikipedias-10-significant-people-EVER.html |title=Jesus Christ tops list of world's top ten most significant people EVER (according to Wikipedia) |author=Sara Malm |date=December 11, 2013 |work=Daily Mail |accessdate=December 22, 2013}}</ref> (only three of the top 100 figures are women),<ref name=telegraph>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/10520730/Aristotle-or-Britney-whos-the-most-famous-of-them-all.html |title=Aristotle or Britney – who's the most famous of them all? |author=Christopher Middleton |date=December 16, 2013 |work=The Telegraph |accessdate=December 22, 2013}}</ref> the authors point out past barriers to women assuming historically significant roles.<ref name=wp>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/religion/jesus-elvis-and-aristotle-whos-bigger/2013/12/12/32968a2a-636c-11e3-af0d-4bb80d704888_story.html |title=Jesus, Elvis, and Aristotle: Who's bigger? |author= Cathy Lynn Grossman |date=December 12, 2013 |agency=[[Religion News Service]] |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=December 22, 2013}}</ref> However, critics have also postulated a bias in the underlying data source,<ref name=tnr/><ref name=leman/><ref name=wp/> since only 15% of English Wikipedia editors are female.<ref name=wp/> The authors acknowledge this as a potential issue (the authors allow that "[T]he English-language Wikipedia is inherently culturally biased... The Wikipedia authors did not leave their prejudices at the door, so any results concerning minorities and gender reflect attitudes as well as accomplishments")<ref>{{cite book |last1=Skiena |first1=Steven |last2=Ward |first2=Charles |title=Who's Bigger?: Where Historical Figures Really Rank |year=2013 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-1107041370}}, quoted in {{cite web |url=http://www.maa.org/publications/maa-reviews/whos-bigger-where-historical-figures-really-rank |title=Who's Bigger? Where Historical Figures Really Rank |author=Alex Bogomolny |date=December 11, 2013 |work=MAA Reviews |publisher=[[Mathematical Association of America]] |accessdate=December 22, 2013}}</ref> and in fact Skiena notes that, statistically speaking, in order to gain a Wikipedia entry a woman has to be somewhat more accomplished than a man.<ref name=leman/> Skiena stated: "Our methods show that for historical figures from the past 300 years, the average significance of women appearing in Wikipedia was substantially greater than that of the average man. This implies that women required greater credentials to get into Wikipedia, analogous to being about 4 IQ points smarter in the mean. Fortunately, this significance gap has closed and essentially eliminated in modern times."<ref name=leman/>
==See also== *''[[The 100: A Ranking of the Most Influential Persons in History]]''

'''Zura Barayeva''' (died October 26, 2002) was the widow of [[Arbi Barayev]], a notorious Chechen warlord. She was killed during the [[Moscow theater hostage crisis]] in October 2002, in which she headed a female unit.[http://www.nordostjustice.org/scgi-bin/media.cgi?cmd=show&lang=en&id=99 Female suicide bombers recruited by teenager]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Gazeta.ru]], 20 May 2003 A former [[hostage]] described her:
"She seemed very normal. She hid her feelings behind a mask of courtesy. She seemed to take pleasure that she was in this situation, that people were listening to her and wanting to talk to her, that she was in control. She would ask people if they had children. She would always say, "Everything will be fine. It will finish peacefully". She took off her bomb belt and carried it over her shoulder, all very relaxed."[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2004/sep/05/russia.chechnya1 Women at heart of the terror cells], ''[[The Guardian]]'', September 5, 2004
